IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis is characterized by progressive scarring of the lung, but how the lung normally reverses scarring to functionally repair tissue is not well understood. The proposed studies will establish robust models in which to study extracellular matrix deposition, the defining characteristic of scarring, and its degradation and resorption. The proposed models will use both primary human fibroblasts and ex vivo tissues cultured from the lungs of individuals with IPF, providing new insight into the failure of scar resorption in IPF, and new targets through which to promote this critical process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We and others have reported a role for pro-inflammatory “inflammasomes” in neurodegenerative disorders. Proposed studies will determine how exposure to pesticides that increase the risk of developing Parkinson’s disease (PD) can activate the inflammasomes in important brain cell types. Completion of the proposed work will improve our understanding of inflammation while informing rapidly advancing efforts to develop therapeutic agents designed to target the inflammasomes so that they can be used for the treatment of PD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative One of the common and unexplained features of Parkinson’s disease (PD) pathology is accumulation of iron in brain regions that are affected by the disease. Our published and preliminary data support a role of the PD gene LRRK2 in iron dyshomeostasis in neurons. We set out to interrogate the role of LRRK2 in affecting the way neurons handle iron, and thus leading to iron accumulation and neurodegeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Obesity increases the hormone estrone, and both obesity and high estrone levels correlate with increased postmenopausal ER+ breast cancer risk. We investigate how actions of the dominant postmenopausal estrogen, estrone differ from premenopausal estradiol and how estrone stimulates unique gene expression patterns to drive the increased risk and mortality from hormone sensitive breast cancer after menopause. This work may reveal how obesity-related inflammation is linked to postmenopausal estrone and increased breast cancer risk and mortality, and ultimately help identify new therapeutic targets for ER+ breast cancer.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The key contribution of this proposal is the development, evaluation, and validation of a machine learning (ML) technique to improve the radiologist’s ability to date infant clavicle fractures—a common, telltale sign of inflicted injury in infants. If successful in the fulfillment of aims, this work will constitute the first rigorously tested and verified application of ML to date fractures with unprecedented precision and accuracy—as well as help buttress the diagnosis of abuse by determining if fractures of different ages are present. We expect this scientific innovation will enable the radiologist to more accurately detect, diagnose and treat this prevalent, life-threatening form of infant maltreatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This application focuses on the roles of the activation of the immune cells within visceral adipose tissue during sepsis in the elderly. We investigate how inflammasome activated-macrophages and adipose B cells contribute to impaired lipolysis during sepsis. The cellular signaling mechanisms that are identified will provide new therapeutic targets to reduce morbidity to septic infection in the elderly.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: Converging lines of evidence indicate that stress, and childhood adversity in particular, accelerates the aging process, leading to impairment, suffering, and disease. The proposed study examines the role of mitochondria in this process, leveraging data available in an existing study of childhood adversity that includes rich data on exposures, health behaviors, and health outcomes. Results of this study are expected to provide insight into the biological mechanisms of risk for accelerated aging and risk for disease, and provide targets for new treatment and prevention approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Type 2 diabetes can be caused by failure to maintain β-cell identity, resulting in dedifferentiation into endocrine progenitor-like cells. In this regard, whether β-cell dedifferentiation is reversible is one of the most important questions in terms of disease modification. This project will examine the reversibility of β-cell dedifferentiation and the potential therapeutic benefits of genetic and pharmacological inhibition of ALDH1A3 on the reversibility of β-cell failure and its potential as a type 2 diabetes treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Post-translational modifications are a well established mechanism of metabolic control. Loss of control is associated with wide-ranging disease states, including the aging process itself. While alterations in protein modifications have been associated with dysregulated metabolism especially in the context of aging, how modifications control metabolism is not known. This key gap in knowledge prevents the generation of effective therapeutics and treatment strategies. Thus, the work described in this proposal is highly relevant to public health because it will determine new mechanisms of action connecting metabolism and nutrient sensing in health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative There is no cure for HIV infection due to the viral dormancy in the infected CD4 T cells. This proposed research is relevant to public health and aims to snip out HIV provirus and knock out viral entry coreceptor CCR5 in HIV latently infected T cells by developing a novel CD4-targeted in vivo lentivirus-like particle delivery of CRISPR/Cas ribonucleoprotein and mRNA. Thus, the strategy to excise provirus and prevent virus entry in this proposal is relevant to the part of NIH's mission that helps develop novel therapeutics for the permanent cure of HIV/AIDS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This project’s relevance to public health stems from its efforts to identify aspects of the bilingual experience that are associated with a significantly later age of symptom onset in Hispanics with language-prominent dementia. In addition, this project will address evidence-based treatment approaches for bilingual speakers with progressive language impairments caused by dementia (i.e., primary progressive aphasia). The project will enhance our knowledge of bilingualism as a contributor to cognitive reserve and brain plasticity which will inform theory and clinical practice in this historically underserved population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Chronic activation of brain microglial cells and attendant neuroinflammation are major factors in the progression of Alzheimer's disease. We identified novel mechanisms that protect against microglial inflammatory hyperactivation and mitochondrial disfunction, resulting in reduced accumulation of amyloid beta plaques and neuronal cell death. These studies may suggest new therapeutic approaches to treatment of Alzheimer's disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Staphylococcus aureus is an important human bacterial pathogen, which is responsible for significant mortality and morbidity on an annual basis. b-Lactam antibiotics have been preferred for treatment of S. aureus infections over the years, however rampant global resistance to these versatile drugs has resulted in obsolescence of many antibacterial mainstays. We investigate in this grant application the complex machinery that results in b-lactam antibiotic resistance in S. aureus. We also seek novel antibiotics and adjuvant agents that have the ability to reverse the b-lactam-resistance trait, bringing back from obsolescence b-lactam antibiotics for treatment of this problematic bacterium.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative While the standard of care for early-stage, estrogen receptor positive breast cancer is breast conserving surgery (BCS) followed by radiation therapy (RT) and 5-10 years of adjuvant endocrine therapy (ET), data from randomized controlled trials support omission of RT in women 65 years and older that take adjuvant ET. However, the majority (70%) of older women still receive RT after BCS, thus raising the concern of over- treatment. Radiation use in this population is multi-factorial, due in part to physician and patient reluctance to omit a treatment in light of concerns that many patients will not complete the recommended course of adjuvant ET due to side effects and thus risk under-treatment. This proposal aims to improve and individualize the treatment of early-stage breast cancer in older women by testing a novel use of a three-month course of pre- operative ET (pre-ET) as a path toward informed decision-making based upon personal experience of ET prior to decisions for adjuvant RT. We plan a clinical trial to evaluate the impact of pre-ET on patient and physician preferences for adjuvant RT and patient-reported decisional conflict and regret.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The strongest genetic risk factor for developing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease is the gene Apolipoprotein E (APOE), where the E4 allele dramatically increases risk while the E2 allele is strongly protective. In this project, we will determine whether ‘allelic switching’ from E4 to E2 will simultaneously rescue multiple neuropathological deficits associated with E4. If successful, this proposal will provide an essential preclinical model for ongoing and future clinical trials, and will provide critical new information regarding opportunities for therapeutic ApoE modulation.

The successful outcome of the proposed studies should define novel mechanism of estrogen regulation and identify potential therapeutic targets for prevention and treatment of cardiac injury in aging female population. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TOLEDO HEALTH SCI CAMPUS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE    Cardiovascular  disease  remains  the  number  one  cause  of  death  in  the  United  States  and  worldwide.  The  proposed  study  utilizes  a  translational  approach  incorporating  the  use  of  transgenic  animal  models,  advanced  smooth muscle cell culture techniques, pharmacological strategies and collaborations with leaders in the field to  rigorously  test  the  hypothesis  that  the  transcription  co- factor  yes- associated  protein  1  induces  smooth  muscle  proliferation and contraction to drive vascular wall thickening and hypertension, respectively. Completion of the  proposed  studies  will  provide  novel  insights  into  the  mechanisms  regulating  vascular  wall  diseases  and  will  determine  if  inhibiting  YAP1  is an  attractive novel therapeutic  strategy  for ameliorating  both occlusive  vascular  diseases and hypertension.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: Alzheimer’s disease and Alzheimer’s disease-related dementia (AD/ADRD) are characterized by severe dementia that interferes with daily tasks, reduced memorization abilities, poor behavior, and inability to think clearly and afflicts nearly 6 million Americans 65 years and older. Clinical trials addressing AD/ADRD require large patient cohorts and are notorious for failures with over 400 unsuccessful attempts last decade. In this proposal, we further develop a non-invasive, at-home AD/ADRD patient monitoring platform that will provide continuous and quantitative measurements of health related biomarkers which in turn will improve the efficiency of clinical trials by providing high-frequency data to inform go/no-go decisions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Parkinson disease causes significant communication problems that negatively affect quality of life, but there are few viable treatment options. Additionally, the underlying disease pathology mediating these deficits, including the neurotransmitter norepinephrine, is not well understood. The primary outcomes of this research will assess benefits and side effects of treatments for communication and its associated behaviors (cognition, affect) and quantify the contribution of norepinephrine as a viable target to treat these refractory deficits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to develop a novel technology platform of widespread applicability for elucidation of the protein interactome of any desired RNA species; as well as the identification of specific lncRNAs and their associated proteins/proteoforms that are differentially expressed in aggressive and indolent prostate cancer. These lncRNAs and their interacting proteoforms will be of immediate use as potential prognostic biomarkers to distinguish aggressive and indolent prostate cancers. There are currently over 180,000 prostate cancers diagnosed in the United States annually and differentiating men that need treatment from those with tumors that can be monitored will have a significant economic and quality of life impact on men with this disease. In addition, the delineation of differentially expressed lncRNAs and their associated proteins/proteoforms will provide insight into the biological mechanisms underlying disease progression and provide novel therapeutic targets for further development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Children with poor early language skills are at risk for academic, social, vocational, and health difficulties across the lifespan. Parent training—as part of early language intervention—is a cost-effective option to address this public health issue, but these interventions demonstrate large individual differences in outcomes and barriers to scalability. The purpose of this research is to examine parent-level predictors of early language interaction quality and modifiability during training, which will help increase intervention effectiveness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mutations in chromatin regulating enzymes are a common feature of many cancer types including lung adenocarcinoma. Our poor understanding of the mechanistic consequences that these mutations have on tumor progression hampers our development of new treatment strategies that exploit molecular vulnerabilities that may exist in these tumors. The overall goal of our project is to identify the molecular aberrations and potential therapeutic vulnerabilities in cancers where SETD2, a chromatin regulating enzyme and tumor suppressor, is inactivated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Heart failure is associated with changes in the surface expression and regulation of the Calcium channel CaV1.2, which contributes to the exertional limitations and propensity for arrhythmia experienced by patients with this disease. Combining APEX proximity labeling with quantitative TMT SPS MS3, I will map the changing “neighborhood” of CaV1.2 in chronic heart failure. Using genetic models of APEX-defined candidate proteins, cellular electrophysiology, and an innovative transgenic mouse model engineered to assess CaV1.2 surface expression, I will gain deep insights into the molecular and cellular pathophysiology of heart failure.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Cartilage injuries and wear result in progressive deterioration of the cells and matrix of the tissue. These changes typically lead to softening of the matrix immediately surrounding cells and are coupled with a pro- inflammatory environment, triggering aberrant cellular behavior and creating a vicious feedback loop that often culminates in joint-wide osteoarthritis (OA). Cartilage deterioration and OA can be debilitating, causing pain, discomfort, and reduced quality of life; Veterans are more than twice as likely to experience these issues due to trauma and wear-and-tear from service. Thus, the goal of the proposed work is to (1) determine the impact of cartilage fortification of the cellular environment on cellular shape regulation and behavior, (2) establish whether combined fortification and inflammatory inhibition synergistically prevent cartilage breakdown, and (3) utilize a matrix-reinforcing and cell-instructive tissue-penetrating hydrogel to preserve cartilage tissue. Altogether, cellular rehabilitation via our “smart” hydrogel system may delay, or even prevent, the onset of OA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: The purpose of this academic/industrial partnership project is to translate an integrated imaging solution for the detection of residual cancer on or near the surface of the surgical cavity after standard-of-care Breast Conservation Surgery (BCS or “lumpectomy”). Consisting of a quenched, fluorescent probe applied topically in vivo to the surgical cavity, and an FDA-approved imaging instrument (the PDE neo, Hamamatsu Photonics), this technology has the potential to reduce repeat procedure rates due to incomplete resection (currently between 8% and 86%), The final, approved platform will have the potential to significantly reduce healthcare costs due to repeat surgeries, with associated reductions in risks of mortality/morbidity and enhancement in patient quality-of-life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Defective repair of DNA lesions causes the accumulation of mutations and genomic rearrangements that predispose to cancer development. MCM8 and MCM9 are tumor suppressor genes that promote DNA repair. Understanding the impact of MCM8 and MCM9 cancer-associated mutations on genomic instability will provide novel and important insights into the molecular events that drive tumorigenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE The blood brain barrier (BBB) is a very important structure that regulates the transport of many molecules that are critical for brain function and health. Endothelial cells, pericytes and astrocytes and critical cells in the formation and maintenance of the BBB and in the regulation of transport of molecules into the brain. However, there are very few tools to study these cells and transport mechanisms in vivo, especially in humans. We have discovered a group of molecules that we think can be used to develop probes to selectively deliver drugs and image these cells in animals and humans. In this proposal we will characterize in depth how these probes work and will do proof of principle experiments to determine their potential as cell specific probes in mice and humans. Finally, we will test the properties of the probes in Alzheimer's disease and stroke mouse models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This work seeks to understand how environmental factors, specifically pesticides, influence the development of Parkinson's Disease (PD) at the level of effects on dopaminergic neurons, the critical cell population lost in PD. Goals of the work include testing how specific pesticides cause damage to neurons derived from PD patient stem cells, and how that damage is influenced by astrocytes and microglia—two other influential central nervous system cell types. Finally, we will begin to set the stage in this proposal for performing “epidemiology in a dish”, growing the stem cells of many PD patients at once, to ultimately test which genetic factors render patients susceptible to pesticides in the first place.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Here we propose to develop a dynamic hydrogel that mimics the complex, multivariate cues of the native ECM to guide the self-assembly of vascular networks from a single cell type. With this biomaterial approach, we aim to control the vasculogenic potential of induced pluripotent stem cell-derived endothelial progenitor cells (iPSC- EPs) and develop a personalized tissue-engineered neovascularization strategy as a clinically viable treatment for peripheral arterial disease treatment. Such a system with superior precision and control of biophysical and spatiotemporal parameters has the potential to revolutionize current methods for creating vascularized tissue for therapy and disease modeling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Narrative This study examines the various effects of Schwann cell pathology on the structure and function of axons in nerve conduction, using genetically modified mice that model inherited human neuropathies. Unexpectedly, these mutations demonstrate that failure to form myelin is not the chief cause of their neurological disability but rather, other factors, including inflammation of their nerves, are critical. Determining how these mutant Schwann cells differentially impact axon biology and nerve inflammation should aid in developing new therapeutic strategies for peripheral neuoropathies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: This proposal is aimed at developing new treatments that will significantly improve the outcome of patients with colorectal cancer. It is based on the idea that clinical efforts to inhibit ERK signaling in colorectal cancer have been limited by insufficient target inhibition due to the high basal receptor driven RAS activation in the colorectum. We plan to profoundly inhibit ERK by co-targeting ERK activation and receptor re-activation and by using novel combinations and dosing schedules that expand the therapeutic index of ERK inhibition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Tumor associated macrophages (TAMs) play an important role in tumor progression, metastasis, immune suppression and therapy resistance, but their function in oncogenic KRAS inhibition resistance is largely unknown. Preliminary study suggests that, forced expression of HDAC5 in pancreatic cancer cells promotes active recruitment of TAMs, which provide TGFβ to support oncogenic KRAS independent tumor growth. This proposal aims to investigate the necessity of tumor-TAMs crosstalk in the bypass of KRAS dependency and explore the therapeutic potentials by co-targeting KRAS and HDAC5-TAM-TGFβ axis in pancreatic cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients infected with severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus-2 (SARS-CoV-2) are increasingly recognized to be suffering from a wide variety of central nervous system complications. This project leverages an innovative and high-throughput pipeline for high resolution mapping of anti-viral antibodies and human proteome-wide detection of autoantibodies from sera and cerebrospinal fluid collected from COVID-19 patients to better understand neuropathogenesis and provide insights into neural mechanisms that underly complex brain functions ranging from coordination to maintenance of mood and personality. Generation of monoclonal antibodies from clonally expanded B cells in the cerebrospinal fluid of COVID-19 patients will enable in vivo mouse studies to deepen our understanding of the potential pathogenic role these antibodies play.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: This proposal investigates a novel idea to explain some aspects of both the initiation of neurodegeneration and dementia diseases, and the spread of disease pathology, in the central nervous system. Based on prior evidence from our lab, our collaborators, and other researchers, we have evidence that elements within our own genomes, namely retrotransposons and endogenous retroviruses, become activated during aging and during initiation of neurodegenerative disease, both through known and unknown causes. This proposal will test the ideas that protein pathologies, specifically in the protein TDP-43, can have a causative role in releasing activity in previously suppressed retroviruses, which can then lead to disease mechanisms within affected cells, and to spread of disease between cells in the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Despite an effective HPV vaccine being available in the US since 2006, uptake is well below the Healthy People 2030 goal of 80%. We will test the effect of standing orders plus communication training for providers and staff compared to communication training alone on HPV vaccination rates. The goal is to understand how best to increase HPV vaccination in primary care, to ultimately reduce HPV-related cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

PHR: Project Narrative This proposal seeks to elucidate the immunosuppressive mechanism of Siglec-15, a novel PD-L1 mutually exclusive T cell immune checkpoint, on the regulation of myeloid cell responses and the identification of its functional receptors on both myeloid cells and T cells. We will further characterize its potential cancer-associated induction mechanism and strategies to improve Siglec-15-targeted therapeutic responses in anti-PD-1- insensitive cancers. The successful completion of our proposed studies will provide important insights to improve the efficacy of our established clinical program and suggest new approaches for next-generation cancer immunotherapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: This proposal aims to evaluate the translational potential of a proprietary tumor-targeted liposomal (TTL) formulation combining a new generation of neuropilin-1 inhibitor having better efficacy and pharmacokinetic parameters and everolimus in a single payload, via preclinical evaluation in multiple relevant mouse models of Glioblastoma Multiforme (GBM). Additionally, a local administration of the liposomes entrapped in a hydrogel system will be compared with systemic administration of the liposomes in an established resection model where the primary tumor will be taken out by surgery before initiating treatment. The most effective formulation will be used for pharmacokinetic and preliminary toxicity studies as a stepping stone for future IND application and potential clinical trials seeking to benefit GBM patients as well as patients suffering from other types of drug-resistant cancer.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Patients with long-chain-3-hydroxyacyl-CoA dehydrogenase (LCHAD) or trifunctional protein (TFP) deficiency develop a unique retinal degeneration that progresses over the lifespan leading to significant vision loss and decreased quality of life. There are currently no treatments for this genetic retinal disorder and the underlying etiology is not fully understood. We propose conducting a detailed prospective natural history study among 44 subjects with LCHAD/TFP to help elucidate retinal pathology, describe the clinical and environmental factors associated with vision loss and estimate the time course and rate of retinal decline across various ages.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We combine proteomic and functional studies in vitro and in vivo to identify novel vulnerabilities for oncogenic KRAS. Preliminary data supports a synthetic effect of loss of RhoA and RAP1GDS1 in KRAS driven lung cancer. Here we will use proteomics, cell biology, biochemistry and in vivo studies in PDX and GEM models to understand the interaction of these two proteins and why they are required in cells carrying oncogenic KRAS mutations.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Neighborhood disadvantage (e.g., poverty and exposure to violence) is a robust indicator of youth adjustment difficulties across most domains of development, yet there are youth who thrive despite significant neighborhood adversity. This project investigates: (1) how resilience changes as youth reach important developmental milestones and freely explore their environments, (2) whether these developmental changes differ by resilience domain (psychiatric, social, emotional, academic), and (3) how warm and involved parenting as well as neighborhood protective factors might shape their development. In doing so, the proposed project can identify specific and modifiable protective factors that promote resilience to chronic neighborhood risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Comorbid Childhood Apraxia of Speech (CAS), a motor speech disorder affecting speech movement planning, may be one factor limiting the ability of some minimally verbal children with autism to acquire spoken language. This project aims to identify a cohort of minimally verbal children who meet criteria for autism and CAS and, using kinematic analysis of speech, to quantify how CAS affects speech movement consistency and precision. The relationship of speech movement parameters, intelligibility, and signs of CAS will be investigated in order to identify movements that are both disordered and intelligibility-reducing. These procedures will be used to create a set of mono- and bisyllabic stimuli, unique to each participant, that can reveal whether CAS-specific treatment, appropriately modified for minimally verbal children with autism, improves their speech.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Individuals with DNA mismatch repair (MMR) gene inactivation have up to three orders of magnitude of increased risk of developing colorectal cancer and other malignancies with microsatellite instability (MSI). However, the genetic basis and underlying mechanisms that determine the rate of disease penetrance is poorly understood. This project will identify the mechanism by which MSI-derived target gene mutation drives CRC tumorigenesis and progression through the centrosome pathway and potentially identify new target to predict and/or treat MSI-associated malignancies.

PHR: Project Narrative  Spinal cord projecting neurons in the Rostral Ventromedial Medulla (RVMSC) plays active roles in chronic pain, but its underlying circuitry and molecular mechanisms are largely unknown. Our proposed studies will help identify novel targets for non-opioid treatment of chronic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inflammation is linked to several CNS diseases, including Huntington’s disease (HD), and cyclooxygenases (COX) play a key role in the inflammatory process, most notably the isoform COX-2. Despite the fact that genetic testing is available to diagnose HD, there remains a critical need to visualize early-stage biological changes in the living brain that occur at disease onset. A COX-2-selective radiotracer for use in positron emission tomography will enable study of disease mechanisms at the molecular level and provide an objective clinical marker to measure therapeutic efficacy in the living HD brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Emerging retrospective data are available linking neonatal sucking to subsequent communication development; however, more prospective and quantitative studies are needed to elucidate the details of this relationship in more detail. The goals of the proposed research are: to establish typical patterns of NNS across infants born full-term (> 37 weeks’ gestation) and moderate to late preterm (born at 32-37 weeks’ gestation) in the first year of life (Aim 1), and to determine the ability of NNS, sampled in infancy, to predict subsequent speech development across patient populations until age three (Aim 2). This study provides an unprecedented level of power in identifying the connection between neonatal sucking and subsequent speech emergence, and results generated will create a paradigm shift in how clinicians approach feeding and speech therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), a major public health burden, can result from defective lung repair/renewal. The primary goal of this project is to define the molecular mechanisms by which FAM13A, a well-replicated gene associated with COPD in genome-wide association studies (GWAS) and enriched in lung epithelial progenitors, responds to extracellular growth factor cues and transduces the signal to intrinsic metabolic controls on the repair capacity of lung epithelial progenitors. This novel concept may shed fresh insights into the biological mechanisms on COPD and pinpoint to new treatment targeting metabolic controls on lung epithelial progenitors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative With the exception of head trauma, diseases of myelin are the major cause of permanent neurological disability in young adults. Myelin insulates nerve fibers and facilitates fast communication between nerve cells. Myelin also provides support that is essential for nerve fiber survival. Neurological disability in myelin disease results from nerve fiber death. This proposal investigates how nerve fibers die as a result of myelin disease. Our studies will identify new ways to treat diseases of myelin and reduce the progression of neurological disability in individuals with myelin disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension (PAH) contributes to high morbidity and death in children with different types of heart, lung or systemic diseases. Despite advances in the development of PAH-targeted drug therapies in adults, there have been very few studies in children regarding safety, effectiveness and the optimal strategies for using these drugs in infants and children with PAH. Using a highly interactive and well-established network of experienced pulmonary hypertension specialists at multiple academic sites, we propose to determine whether early treatment with a combination of medicines will cause greater and more sustained clinical improvement in children with PAH when compared with monotherapy with sildenafil alone.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE    The  public  health  relevance  of  the  proposed  research  is  two- fold:  (1)  The  work  is  expected  to  identify  novel  therapeutic targets for the prevention of substance abuse relapse triggered by drug- associated memory that may  also  be  applicable  to  other  forms  of  aberrant  amygdala- dependent  memory,  such  as  post- traumatic  stress  disorder.  (2)  This  work  is  further  expected  to  profoundly  impact  our  fundamental  understanding  of  the  mechanisms  governing  amygdala  plasticity.  Taken  together,  this  will  significantly  contribute  to  the  missions  of  both NIDA and NIMH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: This research is relevant to public health because it will analyze how a potent cellular regulator of gene expression controls molecular pathways and networks that contribute to epileptogenesis, the process turning a healthy brain into an epileptic brain. The identification and functional analysis of the protein networks that are regulated by the RNA-induced silencing complex after an epilepsy-precipitating event is aligned with NIH’s mission because it will increase fundamental knowledge of the molecular mechanisms underlying epileptogenesis, which, ultimately, could lead to the development of novel more potent therapeutic strategies for epilepsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The relevance of this research to public health: This proposed research will provide insights into how the fungal pathogen Cryptococcus neoformans forms biofilms and coordinates their community behaviors. Despite the prevalence of microbial biofilms and their well-documented involvement in the majority of infectious diseases, little is known about biofilm formation in basidiomycetous fungi, including the major human fungal pathogen C. neoformans. Thus, findings from this exploratory research will fill an important gap of knowledge and provide a foundation for future investigation of the impact of biofilm regulation on fungal pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health, as we will conduct pre-clinical studies of mechanism-based treatments for a new neurogenetic metabolic disorder. The disease mechanisms being studied also have broad relevance to the health of long-projecting neurons, such as those involved in a variety of neurological diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Sudden, unexpected death in epilepsy (SUDEP) is a fatal complication, occurring in patients with epilepsy, who were otherwise healthy. Dravet syndrome, which results from a loss of function of the neuronal sodium channel, is associated with a particularly high risk of SUDEP. This proposal seeks to gain new insights into how regulation of sodium channels inside the heart regulates calcium cycling and underlie heart rhythm disorders and information gleaned from these studies will be used to develop new therapeutic approaches to treat sudden death in Dravet syndrome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Mutations in a specific gene (Apolipoprotein L1 or APOL1) seen only in people of African ancestry (African Americans or Hispanic Americans) is linked to high rates of kidney disease, with only some of the individuals with these mutations developing kidney disease, indicating that other genetic or environmental factors are involved. We will explore these factors including other genes and common environmental exposures like air pollution/neighborhood environment, and heavy metal exposure. We will understand what additional risk factors contribute to kidney disease in individuals with this mutation, which will lead to preventative efforts to address the persistent racial and ethnic disparities in kidney disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: This project addresses our current limitations in the understanding of pulmonary surfactant lipid in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis and it bridges lipid science and respiratory physiology. Pulmonary surfactant is an absolute requirement for lung function as it decreases alveolar surface tension, but the mechanisms for surfactant regulation are not completely understood and therefore not targeted during adult pathologies. By investigating novel mechanisms of surfactant lipid regulation, in the long term this project can enable identification of therapeutic targets to mitigate the decay of pulmonary function during chronic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The ATP-Binding Cassette (ABC) transporters comprise a large family of proteins that use energy from ATP to pump substrates across membranes. We identified an ABC transporter (referred to in this application as G5G8) that is essential for the excretion and homeostasis of cholesterol: people with genetic defects in G5G8 can suffer heart attacks in childhood. In this application we will determine the molecular basis for sterol transport by G5G8, as well as by another sterol transporter G1.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Diabetes affects 13% of US adults and African Americans have higher prevalence of diabetes, higher diabetes related cost, higher risk of complications, and higher risk of early death compared to non-Hispanic Whites and a key factor that is emerging as a significant contributor to poor health outcomes for African Americans is structural racism. A promising intervention that may address the underlying poverty related chronic stress of structural racism and living in inner city environments for African Americans with type 2 diabetes is Cash Transfer, which can be conditional or unconditional. This study will test the preliminary efficacy of diabetes- tailored CCT (DM-CCT), which will be conditional on participating in biweekly (every two weeks), nurse-led, virtual diabetes education/skills training and stress/coping intervention compared to UCT (with no requirement for participation) on clinical outcomes, self-care behaviors, and psychological health in 100 inner city African Americans with poorly controlled type 2 diabetes using an RCT design.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Defects in mitochondria can lead to devastating neurological diseases, including subacute brain neurodegeneration, for which we have no approved medicines. Work in this grant application will provide mechanistic insight into mitochondrial neurodegeneration, while also helping to pioneer new therapeutic approaches. Because mild mitochondrial dysfunction accompanies virtually all age-associated diseases, our work may have implications for more common forms of neurodegeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Iron is required for multiple functions in cells including oxygen transport and its utilization for energy production. Thus iron must be delivered to the brain in a timely manner and in sufficient amounts during development and to maintain optimal function in adults. We conducted investigations to establish the then novel concept that brain iron uptake is regulated at the level of endothelial cells in the blood-brain barrier (BBB) which is in marked contrast to the formally held notion that endothelial cells simply serve as passive conduits for iron transport into the brain. Moreover, in addition to the established role for transferrin, we have identified H-ferritin as a significant iron delivery protein to the brain. The gap in our knowledge addressed in this application is how brain iron uptake is regulated. For these studies we will utilize a combination of animal models and a BBB model derived from induced pluripotent stem cells. The data generated can be expected to impact clinical and therapeutic strategies on management of iron deficiency and its effect on neurological function.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Veterinarians are trained as comparative biologists with an understanding of all living species and ideally suited to solve the complex problems presented by current and future medicine in humans and animals. The goal of the UC Davis Comparative Medical Scientist T32 Training Program is to provide an outstanding environment in biomedical research training at the nation's top-ranked School of Veterinary Medicine and to prepare our students with DVM-PhD degrees to become compassionate and exceptional clinician-scientists engaged in basic and translational research to advance the health of people and animals, in the context of their changing environment. This program addresses a national shortage of research-trained veterinarians who will conduct independent research utilizing animal model systems of human diseases as well as steward appropriate care and use of laboratory animals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic migraines (CM) are among the most common, costly, and disabling conditions in the United States, and there is a significant need for comprehensive, biopsychosocially-informed approaches to management of CM. The current project proposes to test the efficacy of a 2-hour, single-session, telehealth-based behavioral intervention (Empowered Relief) against a health education control condition in addressing CM frequency, intensity, and associated disability. The proposed intervention has the potential to improve the quality of CM management by providing a brief, disseminable, evidence-based treatment for individuals at risk for poor CM-related outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HIV-1 remains a substantial global health burden: antiretroviral therapy (ART) is capable of suppressing virus, but not curing infected individuals. Although broadly neutralizing antibodies (bNAbs) are a highly promising approach for cure, even the most potent molecules are currently only effective for a limited time period. Our goal in this project is to develop an in vivo delivery approach that reprograms B cells to express bNAbs and similar molecules for the lifetime of an individual, enabling long-term HIV-1 remission in the absence of ART.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT (PROJECT NARRATIVE) Genetic and population studies have identified the association between 2 distinct mutations (epsilon2 and epsilon4) in the APOE gene with increased risk and severity of coronary and peripheral vascular disease. This project will establish unique mechanisms by which the expression of the polymorphic apoE2 and apoE4 in myeloid cells and adipocytes contributes to atherosclerosis progression. Completion of this project will yield novel information that can be harnessed to design personalized intervention strategies based on APOE genotype to reduce vascular diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Surgeon-scientists in training have competing clinical responsibilities but must compete for contentious funding lines, which means that state-of-the art training is critical for producing the best surgeon-scientists. With the aging of the population, the number of patients with cardiovascular disease is markedly increasing. The proposed program, with its overarching focus on vascular biology and three distinct tracks including (1) basic/translational, (2) health sciences and (3) biomedical engineering, under multi-disciplinary preceptor guidance, will produce the next generation of surgeon-scientist leaders who will pave the way to new discoveries in human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mental health morbidity is presently an untreated major complication in survivors of acute respiratory failure. In this application, we will explore the feasibility of an intervention aimed at minimizing the psychological distress of intubated patients and will refine the intervention based on stakeholder feedback. We will then study the efficacy of the intervention on short- and long-term mental health and cognitive function of patients who have experienced acute respiratory failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Non-InVasive Neurally Adjusted Ventilatory Assist (NIV-NAVA) is an FDA approved technology that consistently synchronizes non-invasive respiratory support with infant respiratory drive. We propose a Data Coordinating Center (DCC) to support a pragmatic, unblinded, phase III randomized controlled trial (RCT) in preterm infants 240/7-276/7 weeks gestation in respiratory failure to determine if NIV-NAVA, compared with non- synchronized nasal intermittent positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV), prevents extubation failure within 5 days of extubation from mechanical ventilation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The human respiratory system and skin are the body’s largest interface exposed to ambient air and environmental particles, allergens, and microbes. This grant aims to identify homologous human and mouse mononuclear phagocytes in lung, skin and lymph nodes based on functional and transcriptional profiles. Identifying and characterizing mononuclear phagocytes cross-species homologies and the key genes conserved across species that are involved in their function, permits both basic and translational advances, including a more accurate picture of which mononuclear phagocyte subtypes to pursue in a given human application, how to identify these cell types in humans, and which specific genes or proteins to target in treatment development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Tuberculosis (TB) is the world's deadliest infectious disease (other than COVID-19); two keys to reducing this burden of mortality are finding people with undiagnosed TB and providing preventive therapy. Our initial project constructed a “snapshot” of TB transmission in an urban Ugandan community and identified venue-based screening (events held at key locations such as markets) as an efficient case-finding activity. In this renewal, we will conduct a clinical trial to study the implementation and effectiveness of two approaches to venue-based screening and preventive therapy (hotspot-focused and facility-based) with the aim of identifying a feasible strategy to find and prevent TB in peri-urban sub-Saharan Africa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: 8. Project Narrative Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is a disorder characterized by lung scarring and has a prognosis worse than that of most cancers. Improving early detection for idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is an important public health priority. The prior version of this proposal demonstrated the important role that screening in close relatives can have in detecting early stages of pulmonary fibrosis and this renewal expands upon this work while capitalizing on important new and planned genetic and genomic discoveries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension (PAH) contributes to high morbidity and death in children with different types of heart, lung or systemic diseases. Despite advances in the development of PAH-targeted drug therapies in adults, there have been very few studies in children regarding safety, effectiveness and the optimal strategies for using these drugs in infants and children with PAH. Using a highly interactive and well-established network of experienced pulmonary hypertension specialists at multiple academic sites, we propose to determine whether early treatment with a combination of medicines will cause greater and more sustained clinical improvement in children with PAH when compared with monotherapy with sildenafil alone.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The early detection of drug resistance in Candida auris infections is instrumental to the efforts to control and eliminate the disease. Current tools are unable to detect low levels of drug-resistant Candida auris fungi, which limits our ability to study the development of drug resistant Candida auris infections. The goal of this project is to develop and validate a novel design of the polymerase chain reaction for the sensitive and selective amplification of drug-resistant Candida auris species.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE The highly branched structures of dendrites enable the extraordinary connectivity and information- processing power of the nervous system. The overall goal of this application is to develop multi- scale data-driven models that predict quantitatively how the growth of dendritic tips during development gives rise to the morphology of mature dendrites. Bridging genotype to phenotype is expected to provide insight into the pathophysiology of genetic disorders that affect neuronal structures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Transformation of astrocytes into reactive states is recognized as one of the major hallmarks of neurodegenerative disease including prion, Alzheimer’s, and Parkinson’s diseases. However, very little is known about the role of reactive astrocytes in pathogenesis of prion disease. The current project is designed to fill this gap and is the first to critically examine the role of reactive astrocytes in prion diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project investigates the mechanisms by which the innate immune protein Macrophage Migration Inhibitory Factor (MIF) protects against emphysema. In this proposal we will investigate the role of the MIF receptor CD74 and the downstream consequence of cellular senescence as key targets for MIF to mediate its protective effect. Successful completion of these studies may uncover novel therapeutic targets to treat emphysema.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (IPF) is a fatal lung disease characterized by progressive scarring of the lungs. We have recent evidence that matrix stiffness gradients produced in fibrotic lungs promote progressive recruitment of fibroblasts to sites of active fibrosis via durotaxis – the directed migration of cells from regions of lower to higher stiffness. The studies proposed in this application are designed to visualize fibroblast durotaxis in vivo, to define the molecular mechanisms of fibroblast durotaxis and to develop novel therapeutic strategies to inhibit durotaxis in patients with IPF, an incurable and deadly disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The US spends more than $635 billion per year on chronic pain, however, the currently available drugs are not effective and often lead to dependence. Neurobiological, genetic, and preclinical studies have suggested that inhibitors of adenylyl cyclase type I (AC1) offer an alternative target. We propose that the development and characterization of small molecule inhibitors of AC1 as probes will allow us to evaluate and validate AC1 as a new drug target.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Mitochondria are important for stroke survival and can contribute to either adaptation or energetic failure through mechanisms that remain incompletely understood. We propose a novel approach that employs light to directly regulate mitochondrial function to determine when, where, and how it alters the balance between damage and protection during ischemic stroke. We anticipate that this approach will allow us to better understand how mitochondrial function regulates stroke outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative We will translate novel statistical approaches to extract scientifically robust and valid causal evidence of the effectiveness and safety outcomes of antipsychotic drugs used by elderly adults with schizophrenia by exploiting large, observational, longitudinal databases. Our proposal has high public health relevance because (1) we focus on elderly adults with an illness associated with a heavy disease burden for which antipsychotic drug treatments are a critical treatment component, yet drug outcomes for this growing population are poorly understood; (2) we assess the extent to which patient race/ethnicity and social contextual factors known to influence health behaviors may moderate drug outcomes; (3) we characterize the risk and benefits of drug regimens, thus providing valuable information to optimize outcomes of long and complex exposures typical of usual care settings; and (4) we apply generalizable approaches to target parameters of scientific interest for other chronic illness populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed program in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) will provide actionable tools and information from health care data and machine learning to identify early and prevent COPD disease progression and major adverse health care encounters. The risk tools will be used in every day out-patient health care practice to help prevent disease progression requiring home oxygen use, major adverse health care encounters, and improve health care delivery for patients living with COPD in the community.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: The proposed project is relevant to public health because it will identify the sperm factors that induce the Ca2+ release required for egg activation and initiation of development in mammals. Approximately a third of all cases of human infertility is associated with a male condition, and the molecules studied here underlie male infertility, and identifying their function will improve the treatment of infertile patients. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission that pertains to developing fundamental knowledge that will enhance health and reduce the burden of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The presence of autoantibodies in the blood are an important indicator of autoimmune diseases, including those associated with exposure to toxic materials like mercury. An animal model of mercury-induced autoimmune disease will be used to determine the early steps in autoantibody production. These studies will lead to a greater understanding of the development of autoimmune disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Developing more effective prevention strategies for Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) will require more precision-based approaches in terms of identifying who will benefit the most and when. Understanding whether physical activity across the adult life course (e.g., early adult life, midlife, and late-life) contributes similarly or differentially to cognitive resilience will inform more effective prevention strategies for ADRD, based on knowing when modifiable lifestyle interventions will be most beneficial. In addition, identifying predictors of cognitive resilience associated with specific measures of physical activity across the adult life course will help to guide more precision-based participant selection strategies for future clinical trials and interventional studies for the primary prevention of ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The failure of protective neonate respiratory reflexes including the hypercapnic, hypoxic, and auto-resuscitation reflexes are hypothesized to be perturbed in Sudden Infant Death Syndrome and other congenital respiratory disorders. The proposed studies aim to carry out a genetic screen utilizing KOMP-2 mutant mouse strains to uncover genes critical to neonate protective respiratory reflexes and inform upon genetic, molecular, and cellular processes that underly the development and function of neonate respiratory neural networks that may be perturbed in respiratory pathophysiologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Daily rhythms in rest-activity are well-known, but it is unknown how they arise or synchronize to local time. Our preliminary data show that circadian rhythms intrinsic to motor cortex can be entrained in vivo and in vitro. We will test the roles of specific cells and molecules in producing daily rhythms in cortical neurons and astrocytes and in a variety of behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sudden unexpected death in epilepsy (SUDEP) is the most common cause of death in patients with chronic refractory epilepsy, and there are no known preventive strategies. Recent studies indicate the inciting event in SUDEP is seizure-induced loss of breathing, which occurs with seizure spread to the amygdala. This proposal will identify neural mechanisms by which the amygdala influences the brain’s respiratory control network during normal breathing, which is critical to designing safe and effective new therapies for sudden unexpected death in epilepsy (SUDEP) and other neurological disorders that affect breathing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE This project will define whether central autonomic neurons regulate neuromuscular junction transmission and skeletal muscle structure and function, and their vulnerability to cumulative damage over time accelerates sarcopenia and motor deficits in early Alzheimer’s Disease (AD). This study will define the mechanisms by which impaired central autonomic network regulation of the peripheral SNS leads to skeletal muscle sympathetic and motor denervation, and loss in mass and strength, and will enable detection of predementia AD and formulation of effective treatments for each disease stage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE PI: Bagaitkar The NADPH oxidase enzyme complex generates reactive oxygen species (ROS) that are essential in anti- microbial defense. A large body of literature now supports a role for NADPH oxidase derived ROS in the modulation of host inflammatory pathways via redox regulation of immune cell effector functions. We aim to elucidate how ROS modulates neutrophil and macrophage responses in the oral mucosa. Insights gained from these studies would enable us to better understand the chronic inflammation in periodontitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Depression is a recurrent illness and even with successful antidepressant treatment, older adults with late-life depression are at high risk of recurrence. However, neurobiological processes that contribute to vulnerability to recurrence are poorly understood, limiting our ability to target mechanisms in prevention studies. The current study will elucidate neurobiological contributors to recurrence, examine the interrelationship between recurrence and cognitive decline, and provide data on the predictive utility of clinical monitoring in older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project narrative  The apical extracellular matrix (aECM) forms the interface between tissues and the outside world, plays critical roles in organ development and function, and offers a highly accessible therapeutic target. This project will identify novel components of aECM and show how they lead to changes in aECM structure during development. It will reveal how aECM remodelling occurs and will suggest approaches to target this key cellular interface in the context of disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Granulomas drive the course of pulmonary tuberculosis disease and treatment, but we lack detailed understanding of how granuloma features interact with immune function and the bacterial pathogen. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lack of caregiving preparedness is prominent and persistent among care partners of patients living with Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) and associated with increased risk for adverse clinical outcomes for patients living with ADRD, and increased levels of burden, depression, and morbidity for care partners. Engaging key stakeholders to adapt the standardized Care Partner Hospital Assessment Tool for hospital-based dementia care will expand its potential reach. Further, findings from this pilot randomized controlled trial will enable future efficacy trials to advance the refinement and implementation of the decision- support tool that can enhance caregiving preparedness to improve health outcomes after hospital discharge.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because autoimmune diseases, increasing in prevalence, is the top cause of morbidity in women in the United States; and despite significant advances in care, therapeutics usually lead to severe adverse effects due to insufficient selectivity. The proposed research is relevant to the NIH’s mission of reducing illness and disability because we will understand the pathogenic features distinguishing autoreactive T cell subset from normal cells, and this discovery will lead to new therapeutics for autoimmune diseases with substantially improved selectivity and reduced side effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The U.S. aging population is rapidly becoming more racially and ethnically diverse, and better understanding of persistent disparities in dementia diagnosis and care is an urgent research and public health priority. This project will address critical unanswered questions about the associations of social determinants of health with diagnostic and access to care outcomes in a nationally representative cohort of racially and ethnically diverse Medicare beneficiaries. Results will elucidate the mechanisms underlying disparities in ADRD healthcare and will contribute to development of healthcare policy strategies and targeted interventions aimed at reducing inequities in aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bedaquiline and pretomanid are medications from the first new antibiotic classes approved for tuberculosis (TB) by the FDA in 40 years; linezolid was originally developed to treat Gram-positive bacteria but has been found to be effective against TB. Combination treatment regimens using these new drugs have transformed the treatment of drug-resistant TB; however, emergence of resistance to these drugs would undermine the utility of these treatment regimens. We will utilize genomic sequencing, microbiologic and geospatial data, to study the emergence and expansion of resistance to bedaquiline, pretomanid and linezolid in South Africa; this study will provide information that is vital for preserving the effectiveness and ensuring the successful global scale-up of these lifesaving treatment regimens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Asian American women have remarkably high rates of lung cancer, despite that the great majority of them do not smoke; this is a health inequity that has not received the attention that it deserves. Elucidation of lung cancer risk factors among never-smoking Asian American women has the potential to inform the design of targeted interventions to reduce their high burden of this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research aims at understanding key mechanisms in the response to vascular injury with the ultimate goal of developing novel treatment strategies. It is relevant to public health because blood vessels respond to injury by forming blockages that can cause heart attacks and strokes, the most common causes of death in our nation. Thus, the proposed research is directly relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission that pertains to foster research strategies, and their applications as a basis for protecting and improving health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Provision of equitable care and support to Black and Latinx transgender youth and their caregivers is a crucial step in addressing the poor psychosocial outcomes experienced by Black and Latinx transgender persons in adulthood that include depression, substance abuse, and suicidality. The proposed plan will help answer questions about how to optimally support Black and Latinx transgender youth. Findings from the proposed plan will be relevant to the academic and public health arenas and ultimately further the field of pediatric transgender medicine in addressing racial disparities in mental health outcomes and gender affirmation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: 5HT1ARs are highly implicated in mood disorders and SSRI treatment efficacy. More recently, 5HT1ARs have also been implicated in both cognitive and non-cognitive symptoms of Alzheimer’s disease. Importantly, women are more likely to suffer from these disorders, and have a significantly greater response to SSRIs, as compared to men. The mechanisms underlying sex-dependent vulnerability to these diseases and sensitivity to SSRI treatment are largely unexplored. Results gained from our proposed studies will provide an entry point towards better understanding of the sex differences associated with these diseases and SSRI treatment efficacy. Ultimately, information gained from these studies will enable development of personalized strategies to treat these diseases and improve antidepressant efficacy by targeting adult hippocampal neurogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Reducing harms associated with early and problem use of alcohol, nicotine, and cannabis among Black and Latinx youth requires insight into the family and community level cultural and environmental factors most salient to substance use risk in Black and Latinx girls and boys from the pre- to mid-adolescent years. The proposed secondary data analysis project focuses on cultural and environmental factors of particular relevance to members of racial/ethnic minority groups, such as racial/ethnic discrimination and ethnic identity, as well as those more prevalent in Black and Latinx than White youth (e.g., neighborhood disadvantage, religious involvement) to characterize pathways of substance use - from cognitions that precede first use to early onset regular use - from ages 9 to 16. Findings will lay the groundwork for cultural tailoring of substance use prevention strategies for Black and Latinx youth toward the broader goal of reducing substance use related health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement Cochlear implants are remarkable neuroprosthetic devices that restore hearing to people who are profoundly deaf, and are the most widely applied brain-machine interface (500,000+ people worldwide). Outcomes can be highly variable with some people struggling to hear at all- the leading hypothesis is that poor implant use results from lack of neuroplasticity in the auditory system of those subjects rather than device failure per se, but there are little direct data on neural mechanisms of implant use and training. The experiments to be performed in this proposal provide essential data on basic mechanisms of neuromodulation and plasticity in the auditory cortex, required for improvement of prosthetic design and therapeutic strategies for treatment of deafness with implants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Enterocutaneous fistula (ECF) is an abnormal connection between the bowel and skin. It can be associated with discharge of pus, feces, and stomach contents and can even lead to incontinence. The foul enteric contents act as a chemical irritant to the skin, leading to skin breakdown and predisposition to infection. The current treatment paradigm is unsuccessful; high fistula discharge, infection, and chronic inflammation lead to high failure and recurrence rates. We aim to offer a solution in the treatment of potentially fatal ECF using a minimally invasive blood derived biomaterial-based platform to occlude the fistulous tract using groundbreaking injectable shear- thinning biomaterials with anti-microbial and regenerative properties.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Hepatitis B virus (HBV) is a major human pathogen that replicates by reverse transcription of its pregenomic RNA within the viral capsid. HBV pregenomic RNA levels are regulated by the transcriptional coactivator, β-catenin, which also contributes to liver lobule zonation and hepatocellular carcinoma development. A detailed understanding of the mechanism by which β- catenin contributes to viral biosynthesis, hepatocyte metabolism and liver tumor initiation may permit the development of more effective antiviral and cancer therapies targeting the Wnt/β- catenin signal transduction pathway.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Pathologic complete response (pCR) to neoadjuvant chemotherapy (NAC) is strongly associated with improved outcomes, thus the major challenges of NAC are (1) to bring each patient to pCR; and (2) to identify those who are at risk of metastatic recurrence in patients who do not achieve pCR. To this end, biomarkers for prediction of treatment response and accurate estimation of patients’ risk of early metastatic recurrence are needed to guide escalation or de-escalation of treatment in the neoadjuvant and adjuvant settings. In this proposed study, our overarching goal is to develop strategies for combining liquid biopsy (i.e., circulating tumor DNA) and MRI-based (i.e., functional tumor volume) measures of tumor burden to build robust predictors of response and metastatic recurrence, with the ultimate goal of improving outcomes in high-risk early breast cancer patients receiving NAC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative/Relevance To combat the growing diabetes epidemic, islet biologists are striving to develop therapies that preserve or replace lost pancreatic b-cell function and improve patients’ quality of life. To be successful, we must increase our knowledge of fundamental gene transcription and epigenetic mechanisms that drive the development and function of pancreatic b-cells. Completion of our studies will reveal how the Islet-1 transcription factor functionally interacts with the Rnf20 and/or Rnf40 ubiquitin ligases to impact histone modifications and subsequent gene expression governing mouse and human b-cell function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The chemotherapy gemcitabine is the most widely used agent in pancreatic cancer due to its well tolerated profile, even though treatment only marginally extends survival. We found that macrophages within pancreatic tumors facilitate resistance to gemcitabine by releasing metabolites that competitively inhibit gemcitabine cytotoxic activity. This research proposal will define how macrophages create and release these metabolites and then use this information to enhance the efficacy of this well-tolerated chemotherapy.

PHR: Narrative: The goal of this project is to understand the role of HOTTIP mediated aberrant R-loops in CTCF boundary function, leukemic TAD formation, and pathogenesis of AML. PHR: Project Narrative  Obesity is important risk factors in pathogenesis of skeletal muscle insulin resistance and type 2 diabetes. However, the mechanisms by which Western diet and associated activation of the renin angiotensin– aldosterone system promote metabolic syndrome are poorly understood. Understanding the biochemical pathways leading to the muscle insulin resistance and diabetes should provide new strategies in diabetes prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Disturbances in the assembly and disassembly of RNA granules has recently emerged as the key defect underlying common neurodegenerative diseases, such as amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). This project seeks to understand the molecular basis of RNA granule assembly and how this process is disturbed in disease. These insights will be used to guide therapeutic intervention for ALS and related degenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Incisional hernia (IH) persists as an unsolved major surgical health problem with a significant prevalence, insufficient treatments, broad stakeholder impact, diverse risk factors, and challenging epidemiology. Our proposal addresses barriers to IH prevention through multi-source clinical data designed to elucidate and discover key mechanistic drivers of hernia and enable development of performance-optimized, user-informed, parsimonious, specialty-specific models for use within a clinical decision support mobile user interface (CDS-MUI) that will be tested to identify strategies for widespread implementation. This work will lead to a broad, significant, and sustained impact on the field, catalyzing a major pivot towards hernia prevention and enabling precise risk prediction for surgery patients.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Due to physical harms suffered because of persecution in their home countries, asylum-seekers and refugees have significantly high rates of traumatic brain injury (TBI), leading to cognitive impairment that is a substantial source of morbidity for affected individuals, their families, and society. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Certain proteins can regulate cancer and development by regulating gene expression on chromatin. This project will study a fundamental biophysical property of an important protein that is critical in regulating gene expression in cancer and stem cell development. Results from this work will provide important mechanistic insights into how this fundamental property protects us from cancer and also supports development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE: PUBLIC HEALTH IMPACT Epilepsy affects 1 in 100 people with most patients opting not to undergo potentially curative surgical intervention because of the invasiveness of open brain surgery. Making matters worse, 1% of all epilepsy patients (500,000 worldwide – each year!) will die suddenly for unexplained reasons, and even for those who live, 30% will face continual seizures because all available drugs will fail for them. This project focuses on providing a minimally invasive way to achieve the benefits of surgery without opening the skull, through use of a steerable needle delivered through the patient's cheek, with thermal therapy delivered to the brain and monitored in real time using MR imaging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative We have identified a role for the heat shock protein (HSP) receptor CD91 in initiation of immune responses against nascent, emerging tumors. These immune responses are central for immunosurveillance of cancer, a concept proposed over a hundred years ago. In this proposal we aim to examine the interaction of CD91 with its ligands, the HSPs, on hematopoietic cells in situ as the mechanism that leads to productive anti-tumor immune responses. By understanding this immunological pathway we will solve an outstanding question that is central to cancer immunology and also be better able to predict individuals that have poor CD91 function and are more susceptibility to developing cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Narrative This UCSF training grant (DaTABASE) will provide training in advanced data analytics to predoctoral researchers studying behavioral and social determinants of health. The program is a collaboration between the UCSF Department of Epidemiology and Biostatistics, Bakar Computational Health Sciences Institute, and the Center for Health and Community. Unique strengths of the program include 1) a focus on health disparities; 2) exceptional clinical and population data sources; and 3) integrating advanced machine learning methods into causal frameworks for actionable results.
