IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project aims to provide the first systematic functional characterization of a novel category of genomic features, translated small Open Reading Frames. This research is relevant to public health because new functional annotations at these regions of the human genome will bring clarification to the coding and non- coding classification of the human transcriptome, which will be useful in interpreting molecular mechanisms and predicting functional impacts of genetic variants linked to these loci.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Appendiceal adenocarcinoma (AA) is a rare orphan malignancy for which there is a great lack of both clinical trials data and molecular understanding to guide treatment. In this project we will develop a working knowledge base of the genetic alterations that underlie this disease, and pursue development of actionable genetic tests to guide critical AA treatment decisions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: One-in-four adults hospitalized for community-acquired pneumonia experience an adverse cardiac event. This is, in part, the result of Streptococcus pneumoniae invasion of cardiomyocytes. Herein, we determine how glucose limitation experienced by intracellular pneumococci enhances their production of cytotoxic pneumolysin and hydrogen peroxide; together resulting in cardiomyocyte death.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The goal of this this application is to determine the functions of the trypanosome RNA binding protein, DRBD18, in controlling alternative polyadenylation and cell phenotype. DRBD18 is essential in both human and insect stage T. brucei, and conserved in kinetoplastid parasites. The proposed studies will significantly increase our mechanistic understanding of this essential protein in these medically and economically important parasites.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have uncovered a new functional link between the ARID1A chromatin remodeler and the process of mRNA translation elongation important for urothelial cell maintenance and cancer pathogenesis. This discovery is clinically significant, as ARID1A-deficient cancers are exquisitely sensitive to inhibition of translation elongation initiation. Our goal is to definitively investigate the functional link between chromatin remodeling and protein synthesis control, as well as determine the therapeutic implications of targeting this interface.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Failure of the functionally mature state of insulin-secreting beta cells in the pancreas (sometimes called beta cell de-differentiation) under conditions of obesity and insulin resistance leads to diabetes. Recent evidences support a hypothesis that five new genetic regulators control the functionally mature beta cell state. The goals of this application are to elucidate the mechanism(s) by which these five regulators control mature beta cell state and to identify strategies to manipulate their expression or activity as means to prevent beta cell failure in diabetics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Interstitial lung diseases (ILDs) including idiopathic and other forms of pulmonary fibrosis are a major and growing medical burden. Fibrosis progression in these diseases is driven by the persistent activation of fibroblasts; understanding how fibroblasts become activated and then locked in fibrogenic states is central to the development more effective therapies for fibrotic ILDs. The proposed studies will test the role and regulation of the transcription factor Runx1 in fibrogenic cell activation and memory in mouse models and human tissue, potentially identifying a novel targetable mechanism underlying fibrotic ILD progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The co-assembly of two synaptic nanoscopic structures that release and restore neurotransmitters is at the core of information processing in the brain and is altered in psychiatric disorders. This proposal investigates the pathways that co-assemble these essential machineries. This provides fundamental insights into information processing and into pathways affected in brain disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project will test an innovative intervention that integrates financial coaching into a smoking cessation program for low-income smokers. Study results will address large gaps in knowledge about how to reduce tobacco use among low-income adults, with emphases on applying socio-contextual theory and behavioral economic theory to target financial stress, delay discounting, and attention as barriers to quitting in this highly vulnerable population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Catheter-associated urinary tract infections (CAUTIs) are the most common cause of hospital- associated infections and can result in severe disease and increased mortality. This proposal seeks to define the host-pathogen interactions, and specifically the contribution of the virulence factor urease, that facilitate CAUTI caused by Staphylococcus aureus in catheterized individuals. Additionally, this research will provide the platform for the career development of a young investigator focused on translating basic science research in host-pathogen interactions, molecular microbiology, and novel drug development into clinically useful interventions to improve patient care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE MLL-rearrangement (MLL-r) affects about 10% acute leukemia patients and is associated with poor prognosis. This proposal has immediate clinical relevance in developing a more advanced treatment to MLL-r leukemias, and will contribute to a broader understanding of how the dynamic epigenetic networks control oncogene expression in cancers and therapeutic responses. The technology developed in this project will facilitate functional domain discovery for future targeted therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: We will identify a fundamental mechanism that determines the distance between origins of DNA replication in human cells. This mechanism is a key determinant of genome stability and the rate of cell division, and accordingly it is a key determinant of therapeutic response in the medical and radiation oncology clinic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Receiving a diagnosis of prediabetes does not always result in developing diabetes. Substantial reduction in the risk of developing diabetes can be made through lifestyle changes, like adopting a healthier diet and increased physical activity; however, for older people access to support systems for achieving a healthy weight and exercise program can be restricted. Our study examines ways to increase access for older adults to support a healthy lifestyle.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Mutations in the gene that encodes the type I ryanodine receptor (RYR1) in skeletal muscle are the most common causes of malignant hyperthermia susceptibility (MHS) and environmental heat stroke (EHS). For unknown reasons, families with RYR1 mutations display variability in penetrance, expressivity, and genetic discordance. This project will define the molecular mechanisms that underlie variability in MHS/EHS penetrance, expressivity, sex-bias, and genetic discordance, as well as provide new information on the complex interplay of environment and genetics in these disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a devastating blood cancer with limited therapeutic options. Relapse is the main cause of treatment failure, most likely due to the persistence of tumor precursor cells (leukemia initiating/stem cells) that are resistant to current treatments. It remains a critical challenge to develop effective therapeutics to eradicate these cells. The project proposed in this application seeks to target the metabolic vulnerability of these cells through inhibition of PTPMT1 that plays an important role in cell energy production. If successful, this effort may lead to a novel strategy to deplete these root cells in AML.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The HIV Centers for Underrepresented Populations in Research Clinical Trials Unit (CURE CTU) will be comprised of six highly experienced research sites located at Texas Children’s Hospital, Baylor College of Medicine in Houston, TX, Ann & Robert H. Lurie Children’s Hospital of Chicago, IL, Northwestern University, St. Jude Children’s Research Hospital and the University of Tennessee Health Science Center in Memphis, TN, University of Miami, Holtz Children’s Hospital, Miami, FL, Children’s National Medical Center in Washington, DC, and the University of California, San Diego, CA; each located in an area targeted by the U.S. initiative to end the HIV epidemic. The CURE CTU is the only unit specifically focused on research in pregnant women, women, children, adolescents and young adults less than 25 years in the continental U.S. funded through NIAID. The Specific Aims of the CURE CTU address many of the targeted high priority areas of the 4 NIAID proposed Networks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) is the most common form of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma and encompasses molecular subtypes with contrasting biology and clinical outcome. Conventional chemo- and immuno-therapy combinations fail to cure approximately 40% of DLBCL patients, and this relapsed/refractory population has a very poor prognosis. Investigating the molecular drivers of poor outcome and how these may be targeted with rational therapeutic strategies is likely to improve the outcome of these patients and have a substantial impact on public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative People are exposed to per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances daily from multiple sources. Epidemiological studies show an association between serum PFAS concentrations and lower bone density in both children and adults. Here, we investigate a new in vivo model to study the mechanism through which PFAS impair bone health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative  This project addresses a critical gap in knowledge regarding the prospective role of social connectedness in shaping health for the Blackfeet American Indian community, a health disparity population. The findings from this longitudinal investigation will elucidate biopsychosocial pathways which may connect social connectedness to health-relevant outcomes in the Blackfeet community. This knowledge will inform future health interventions for the Blackfeet community and AI communities with similar values and health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Anti-insulin B cells (AIBCs) create type 1 diabetes (T1D) liability, yet the processes by which AIBCs acquire insulin-binding B cell receptors and expand early in human T1D are not clear. To address this knowledge deficit, we will determine AIBC phenotypic and B cell receptor attributes, and how they change as pre- symptomatic T1D TrialNet participants progress towards diabetes. These studies are required to enable future investigation of AIBC changes as sensitive biomarkers to predict diabetes onset and identify favorable clinical trial responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The majority of human neurological and psychiatric disorders involve impairment in learning and memory. This research program delves into the process of memory formation, with a focus on the brain mechanisms that mediate forgetting, how the brain organizes memories, and the roles for genes that suppress memory formation. The knowledge obtained from these studies will provide new information that may lead to diagnostics or therapies for brain disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Hanson’s disease (HD), more commonly known as leprosy, is a zoonotic infection in the United States. Transmission to humans by blood-feeding arthropods (insects and ticks) has long been suspected. This project seeks to examine the interaction between Mycobacterium leprae and vector ticks to better understand the ecology of this ancient disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Autism affects the brain’s capacity to interpret and respond to social information, including human faces. This study will advance our understanding of how early brain development associated with visual face learning in the first two years of life relates to social ability in autism. Our developmental neurobiological approach has potential to provide a novel biomarker of a specific and foundational social skill, which could in turn inform early detection and intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Standard-of-care prostate cancer treatments targeting the androgen receptor transcription factor exert selective pressures that can lead to the emergence of lineage plasticity phenotypes that are difficult to treat and poorly-understood. This proposal seeks to understand the role and therapeutic potential of a stem cell transcription factor that is up-regulated by prostate cancer treatments and promotes early events in prostate cancer lineage plasticity. We will test the efficacy of blocking this stem cell transcription factor, as well as inhibiting its downstream targets, to treat, prevent, or reverse the emergence of lineage plasticity in prostate cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: A limiting barrier in developing effective treatments for Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the lack of understanding of  how Abeta and tau cooperate to trigger and exacerbate this disease. We recently uncovered more than one  hundred genes capable of modifying the synergistic damage caused by Abeta and tau in a fruit fly model of AD  and we plan to interrogate them molecularly and genetically to selectively identify the most robust and promising  targets. Therefore, this research is relevant to public health because it has the potential to identify new genes  and molecular pathways that could block, delay, or prevent this devastating disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The vertebrate left-right (LR) body axis specifies the proper anatomical position and morphology of multiple organs; thus, abnormal LR asymmetry, known as heterotaxy (HTX), can cause catastrophic syndromes of laterality-related birth defects. In the proposed project, we test the idea that the asymmetry of a specific organ, the stomach, is shaped by LR asymmetries in cellular metabolism. As such, this research may help resolve previously unexplained causes of human laterality defects involving mutations in metabolism genes or environmental disruptions of maternal and/or embryonic metabolic homeostasis.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer death among Veterans, and Black men have the highest rate of lung cancer diagnoses and deaths of any group in the US. Lung cancer screening with yearly chest scans can prevent lung cancer deaths, but only 10% of eligible Veterans have been screened, with lower rates among Black people than white people. Outside the VA, trained community peers are effective to increase cancer screening rates among minority populations. In this pilot project we will develop a Veteran Peer Specialist-led program to support and empower Black Veterans to engage in lung cancer screening. The Peer-led program will be designed with input from Black Veterans and will include community outreach, group education, and one-on-one support personalized to the needs of individual Black Veterans. We will pilot test this program in the VA Boston Healthcare System in partnership with local community organizations that serve Black Veterans. This pilot work will allow us to refine the Peer-led program and to plan a subsequent multi-site study.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Every day, Veterans across the Veterans Health Administration (VHA) are discharged home with vascular access devices for delivery of outpatient parenteral antimicrobial therapy (OPAT). Although OPAT is a vital part of Veteran care, we know very little about how it is managed or the challenges Veterans and their caregivers experience. Because adverse events are possible, this information is critical to identify gaps in care and develop strategies for Veterans to receive safe, effective therapy. This study engages Veterans, caregivers and clinical care providers using multiple methods including semi-structured interviews, surveys, video reflexive ethnography, and photo elicitation to gain a deeper understanding of the challenges encountered related to the delivery and administration of at-home OPAT. We will also engage these stakeholders in a collaborative co-design process to develop interventions for improving OPAT care and management at home. Importantly, this work will inform OPAT related policy and practice within VHA.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Falls are a major health concern in older Veterans. Evidence suggests that abnormalities, related to disuse, in muscles of the hips may have a major role in fall risk. This application will use novel methods of exercise to address improving the muscles of the hips as a means of reducing falls. If successful, this application will provide new practical methods to improve balance and reduce falls by improving the hip muscles in older Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: This research project will provide insight into how a newly identified metastasis pathway, previously implicated only in blood cell trafficking, could be exploited to inhibit melanoma progression. Our studies will validate, in pre-clinical melanoma models, the potential therapeutic utility of commercially available pathway inhibitors used in other disease settings, for blocking cancer metastasis. Results from this project will yield the first in- depth target characterization in clinical tumor biospecimens and pave the way for the development of more potent and cancer-selective therapeutics targeting this cellular trafficking pathway.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Altered circadian rhythms and impaired mineral balance, including excess circulating phosphate (Pi) and fibroblast growth factor (FGF)-23, are two hallmarks of progressive Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD). FGF23 and Pi are associated with faster CKD progression and mortality. This project proposes to test the disruption of the kidney circadian clock as a mechanism mediating FGF23 and Pi adverse effects on kidney function, thus providing potential therapeutic targets for individuals with CKD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: U54 CENTER NARRATIVE Despite rapid advances in new anti-cancer therapeutics, for many solid cancers complete remission is still rare. In many cases, tumors eventually develop resistance to treatments. One of the major barriers to effective therapeutics is likely to be potentiated by highly transcriptionally plastic cancer stem cells. In this U54 Northwestern University Center for Chromatin Nanoimaging in Cancer, we will develop, optimize, test, and deploy new nanoimaging technologies, integrated with state-of-the-art molecular and computational methods, to address some of the long-standing questions related to the origin of cancer stem cells and their ability to adapt to chemotherapies. Addressing these fundamental knowledge and technology gaps may help identify new therapeutic strategies that prevent tumor resistance to therapeutics and relapse after treatment.

PHR: Project Narrative Up to 97% of gender-diverse individuals assigned female at birth have gender-related voice problems, yet there are currently no evidence-based treatments for voice masculinization. Gender-affirming hormone therapy with exogenous testosterone is the default treatment, yet we still do not know how and when it works, nor in whom. The project will allow for evidence-based guidance about when and how communication will be impacted by testosterone therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disorder that places substantial burden on the medical and public health systems. Pancreatic islet dysfunction and failure is central to type 2 diabetes. In this project, we apply innovative genomic profiling and (epi)genome editing technologies to determine the genetic programming and cellular control of human islet metabolic and endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress responses, which are fundamentally linked to islet dysfunction and T2D pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Persons with urinary stone disease have an increased risk of fracture yet no guidelines exist to help providers screen or manage these persons for osteoporosis. The underlying cause of skeletal fragility in urinary stone disease is poorly understood. This project proposes to identify persons with urinary stone disease at highest risk of fracture and to understand the skeletal status in persons with urinary stone disease so that early diagnosis and treatment can be instituted to prevent fracture.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to examine serotonin projections and signaling that regulates food intake by targeting the neural circuits connecting zona incerta and paraventricular thalamus, two brain areas are recently confirmed to be important in the feeding control. Therefore, the proposed studies in this application will help understand the role of the central serotonin system in the regulation of food intake and the involvement of dysfunctional serotonin signaling in overeating and obesity. The results from this project will shed light on a new target in the pharmacological treatment of obesity and eating disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding the regenerative response of the nervous system in models that naturally regenerate is integral to the development of potential therapies for traumatic brain injury and stroke. The proposed studies in the zebrafish seek to investigate the mechanisms through which meningeal lymphatics contribute to adult neurogenesis and regeneration of the nervous system by regulating the immune response and composition of cerebral spinal fluid. Through these studies we will gain novel insights into the mechanisms that underpin the relationship between the lymphatic system and promoting the regenerative response of the central nervous system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Advances in diabetes technology such as continuous glucose monitors (CGM) have the potential improve health outcomes for youth with type 1 diabetes, but adolescents are the least likely to use CGM, are at relatively high risk for underutilizing or discontinuing this technology, and access is challenged by significant health disparities. This project proposes to pilot an intervention incorporating behavioral strategies to optimize CGM use and reduce related psychosocial barriers. The findings of this pilot work will initiate a trajectory of research responsive to the needs of young adolescents, including youth from historically underrepresented racial and ethnic backgrounds and youth with public insurance, related to new diabetes technologies with significant potential to improve health outcomes and clinical diabetes education and care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Follow-up imaging for glioblastoma patients is challenging to interpret due to subjectivity in evaluating disease state and overlap between treatment effects and tumor progression. More objective follow-up criteria are vital for sensitive and accurate monitoring of glioblastoma patients after initial treatment to ensure proactive management of disease and accurate characterization of tumor recurrence. This research proposal will develop user-friendly quantitative software for lesion segmentation and disease-state assessment, providing unbiased metrics for post-treatment patient monitoring and guidance of management decisions in clinical and research settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  The rapid rise in antibiotic resistance coupled with a dwindling antibacterial pipeline, particularly for Gram- negative pathogens, has collectively contributed to multi-drug resistant infections being deemed one of the biggest threats to global health. While recent advances have led to an understanding of the physicochemical traits guiding compound entry in Gram-negative bacteria, promiscuous compound efflux still remains poorly understood and is detrimental to antibacterial activity. This proposal seeks to define features necessary for compound recognition and expulsion by efflux pumps in E. coli and to codify these physicochemical properties into actionable guidelines for engineering efflux liabilities out of antibacterial candidates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: In the classical view of chronic or excess glucocorticoid exposure, glucocorticoids convey their signals through an intracellular glucocorticoid receptor that acts with various coregulator proteins to modulate the transcription of specific target genes, which induce insulin resistance, a risk of type 2 diabetes. Here, we will examine a novel model in which glucocorticoid receptor coregulator, Ehmt2, specifically activates genes that promote insulin sensitivity to limit the insulin resistance caused by the glucocorticoid receptor acting with other coregulators. The knowledge gained from this revolutionary model will provide novel  therapeutic insights into treating type 2 diabetes.

PHR: Project Narrative Cellular shape change is a fundamental characteristic of cells, key to development, physiology, and pathology. The morphogen netrin promotes neuronal development and cancer progression, yet we know little about how cells interpret netrin into shape changes. Our work exploits developing neurons and migrating melanoma cells as model systems to examine how netrin alters cellular shape during development and metastasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE HIV infection can be treated and to some extent prevented with effective medications, but this alone has not resulted in sufficient progress worldwide to expect an end to the HIV epidemic. In addition, persons who are infected with HIV, even if they are receiving effective medication treatment, continue to have health consequences that likely persist for life; in many cases, they remain at risk for other infectious complications as well. The Case CTU plans to contribute to research to improve the options to deliver HIV treatment, to find an effective and universal HIV vaccine, to achieve long-term control of HIV in infected persons, and to understand lethal infectious complications such as tuberculosis and hepatitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE To identify new therapeutic targets against MRSA, we will study the trafficking of surface proteins, which are essential for S. aureus colonization and disease pathogenesis. Our proposal will reveal the mechanisms of septal membrane assembly, regulated cleavage of YSIRKxxxGxxS precursors at septal membranes and precursor activation of SecYEG translocons for their secretion into the cross-wall compartment. Our studies are expected to provide insights into the mechanisms of surface protein secretion and assembly in other drug- resistant bacteria, including vancomycin-resistant enterococci, penicillin-resistant pneumococci and antibiotic- resistant Clostridium difficile.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA SALT LAKE CITY HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: My research can revolutionize how VA patients with amputations connect their external prosthetic device to their residual limb, helping them to maximize their functional recovery and their quality of life. <<My work ranges from basic bench-top science, to trials with translational animal models, and to FDA monitored clinical trials with the goal of bringing safe, FDA approved percutaneous osseointegrated (OI) devices to this deserving patient population. The concept of OI is based on the ability of human bone cells to attach to a metal surface. OI has been used for decades to anchor dental prosthetic devices. More recently, a common paradigm in orthopaedics with hip, knee, and shoulder arthroplasties, uses OI to anchor an endoprosthesis surgically implanted into the bone and within the body. My research takes me outside this paradigm. I engineer percutaneous OI devices, which require a load-bearing metal post to be connected to the OI endoprosthesis, passing permanently through the skin to be connected to the distal componentry outside of the body.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The first steps in gene expression – those encompassing the synthesis of RNA – touch every process in the cell and can be compromised in disease, including disease arising from defects in the RNA synthesis machinery itself. The proposed studies in model organisms such as Baker’s yeast, fission yeast, and Drosophila allow a deep understanding of how and where gene expression begins in eukaryotes involving factors conserved across eukaryotes, including humans. In parallel, experiments illuminate questions universal to eukaryotic cells: how the machinery for RNA synthesis navigates the genome and how connections between RNA synthesis and transcript processing and chromatin remodeling come about.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative The extent to which cancer tissue is completely removed during surgery of intracranial tumors is an important prognostic indicator of local recurrence and overall patient survival; however, current and new approaches designed to guide resection have major shortcomings. To solve this problem, we are advancing a new strategy for surgical guidance that aims to use injected optical contrast agents to reproduce the diagnostic information provided by pre-operative contrast-enhanced MRI images. Contrast-enhanced MRI imaging is the standard reference for diagnosis, surgical navigation and post-treatment monitoring of intracranial tumors; and thus, transferring this important information into the visual surgical field will be a major development to help surgeons maximize tumor clearing.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS AFFAIRS MED CTR SAN FRANCISCO
PHR: The proposed CDA-2 will provide Dr. Kornblith with the training, expertise, and hands-on experience necessary to advance research on cognitive rehabilitation for aging Veterans with traumatic brain injury (TBI), and increase access to such treatment. Using technology to deliver effective treatment for cognitive problems associated with TBI to Veterans at home may result in improved daily functioning and increased access to health care for the growing population of aging Veterans with history of TBI. The successful completion of this project may also increase older Veterans’ ability to participate in research through increased understanding of the effect of in-home research opportunities on recruitment and retention. Additionally, the evidence gathered from this study may be used in future research studying home-based cognitive rehabilitation treatments for Veterans using telehealth technology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  KRAS is one of the most prevalent and vicious cancer proteins, yet no drugs are available to inhibit its pathologic activity in human cancers. We have discovered that an all-hydrocarbon “stapled” peptide modeled after the KRAS-interacting helix of SOS1, a natural KRAS agonist, can inhibit oncogenic KRAS signaling by competitive dissociation of the SOS1/KRAS complex and, unexpectedly, by directly and independently blocking KRAS nucleotide association by an unknown mechanism. By combining the synergistic and interdisciplinary expertise of the Engen and Walensky laboratories, we aim to achieve new insight into the structure-function mechanisms of KRAS modulation by the SOS1 protein and SOS1- derived stapled peptides, and thereby advance a novel therapeutic approach for disarming KRAS in human cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT: Psychiatric disorders including major depressive disorder (MDD) are widespread, yet they are difficult to diagnose and treat due to a lack of available biomarkers. The discovery of biomarkers whereby those at high risk for psychiatric disorders can be identified would lead to optimized patient care, improved patient outcomes, and more efficient allocation of resources. As such, the proposed research aiming to identify epigenetic signals from brain tissue samples associated with psychiatric disorders, especially MDD, and their correlation to epigenetic signals from peripheral tissues is expected to provide a novel approach that can inform the prevention of MDD. Further, it is likely to also facilitate the development of treatments for patients who experience MDD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: This research grant is designed to determine whether chronic treatment with mirabegron, a β3 adrenergic receptor agonist approved for treatment of over active bladder, improves metabolic homeostasis in prediabetic, obese, research participants. We will also investigate the underlying mechanisms for improved β-cell function and insulin sensitivity by mirabegron treatment, which we recently demonstrated. There is a tremendous need for new approaches to fight the obesity and type 2 diabetes epidemic, and this research is thus highly relevant to human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative: The proposed research is relevant to the public health because it interrogates the mechanisms underlying neural developmental deficits with key pathogenic roles in Huntington’s disease. More specifically, it will define what processes adversely influence the elaboration of interneurons, how their reductions impact the maturation of relevant brain circuits, and whether these deficits yield neuronal species more susceptible to stressors. Accordingly, this research would uncover mechanistic cascades that will provide the substrate for the development of therapeutic paradigms aimed at modifying disease progression, which is relevant to the goals of NIH’s overall strategic mission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative  Liver cancer, especially hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), is the fastest growing cancer in US with no effective treatment. We are conducting research to identify HCC-specific T cell receptor (TCR) that can be used to engineer human T cell to become highly effective TCR-Ts to kill tumor cells without causing significant toxicity to normal cells. This proposal allows us to gather sufficient data to apply for clinical trials and eventually leads to new immunotherapy for hepatocellular carcinoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Solitary Fibrous Tumors (SFTs) are an understudied tumor with an unclear pathogenesis, about a fifth of cases become malignant and unresponsive to treatments. There are no known recurring mutations in SFTs other than an intra-chromosomal inversion that leads to a gene fusion between NAB2 and STAT6, which produces a chimeric protein with an unknown function. Understanding the role the NAB2-STAT6 fusion protein plays in gene expression will lead to greater understanding of SFTs development and progression to malignancy, and may elucidate therapeutic targets for the treatment of SFTs.

PHR: Project Narrative The purpose of our studies is to identify novel therapeutic vulnerabilities for a common type of aggressive lymphoma (diffuse large B-cell lymphoma) by understanding the role of lymphoma associated fibroblasts that are part of the tumor microenvironment. If successful, these studies will launch the development of specific and likely low-toxicity treatments that could benefit patients with incurable lymphomas.

PHR: Project Narrative Sexual and gender minority (SGM:, e.g., lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender) adolescents experience disparities in behavioral health outcomes compared to their peers. The goal of this grant is to test the efficacy of a theoretically informed, multi-level school-based intervention for SGM adolescents, Proud & Empowered (P&E). Based upon our extensive preliminary studies and pilot data, we expect that P&E will help to a) reduce minority stress; b) improve behavioral health and coping along SGM; and c) create sustainable change in school climate to improve the health of this high need population of youth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: Narrative: Pancreatic Ductal Adenocarcinoma (PDAC) takes advantage of its surrounding tissue to promote its malignant growth and evade the immune system. To understand how cellular interactions within the PDAC ecosystem impact clinical outcome, I propose to build and characterize a detailed single-cell transcriptomic atlas of the PDAC microenvironment at an unprecedented spatial and transcriptional detail. This hybrid tumor mapping will serve as a valuable bioinformatic resource by lending researchers the ability to investigate targetable cell signaling interactions within the cancer tissue landscape.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Project Narrative Periodontitis is a common inflammation of the tooth supporting tissues due to infection by a select group of bacterial pathogens. It can lead to tooth loss in adults and also impact systemic health. The objective of this project is two-fold: to understand how pathogen secreted sialidase enzymes – which can release sialic acid sugar from host components – influence periodontitis, and perform proof-of-concept studies in mice to assess if FDA-approved inhibitors of this enzyme can prevent periodontitis in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Colorectal cancer is the 2nd leading cause of cancer death, and despite effective methods for prevention and early detection, screening rates remain low. Recent insights from behavioral economics have shown that reducing effort and providing timely nudges can encourage clinicians and patients to engage with preventive health activities. We will conduct a pragmatic trial evaluating if offering a sequential choice of screening options during clinic visits and through direct patient outreach can increase colorectal cancer screening completion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal is aimed at a better understanding of how the brain controls food intake and body weight through a newly identified neural circuit in response to external stimuli and calorie-dense foods. Here, we begin to identify two distinct group of neurons from a defined brainstem neural circuit that elicit complementary roles in regulation of feeding behavior and obesity. The expected outcome would facilitate the discovery of new, brainstem targets for therapeutic weight-management strategy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Clinical prognoses after surgical breast reconstruction often involve mastectomy skin flap necrosis or other complications associated with lack of blood flow and oxygenation to wound tissue volumes. The objective of this project is to design and optimize a novel noninvasive optical imaging technique, which will enable rapid online 3D imaging of both blood flow and oxygenation distributions throughout the entire volume of mastectomy skin flaps to perioperatively assess ischemic-hypoxic tissue regions/volumes. Outcomes from this translational study in swine and patients undergoing mastectomy with expander-implant based breast reconstruction will provide essential information for intraoperative guidance of compromised tissue excision and postoperative optimization of incremental expander fill volumes to reduce postmastectomy complications and healthcare costs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The aims described in this application seek to determine novel mechanisms of group 1 ILC dysregulation in acute myeloid leukemia (AML). We propose an innovative approach to discover the mechanism(s) leading to expanded ILC1 populations in AML and to determine the functional significance of these expanded populations on overall disease progression. PHR: Project Narrative The expertise provided by the Statistical and Data Management Center will help advance research concerning the treatment of infants, children, adolescents, pregnant and breastfeeding women living with HIV and co-infections such as tuberculosis. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Parkinson’s disease (PD) is a debilitating neurodegenerative disease that affects ~1 million individuals and their families nationally. The majority of PD incidences are idiopathic, and pesticide exposures are thought to be a contributing factor to disease etiopathogenesis. This project will explore the interaction of environmental exposures and the microbiome in outcomes of PD-relevant pathologies, with the goal of providing insight into how the indigenous gut microbial community modifies environmental signals leading to brain pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT  Genetic mutations in the elastin gene cause reduced elastin protein levels and lead to severe narrowing (stenosis) of the aorta through a mechanism that is not well understood. The project will determine how mechanotransduction in smooth muscle cells within the aortic wall is modified by reduced elastin levels and how the resulting downstream signals may contribute to aortic narrowing. The results may lead to new therapeutic strategies to slow or prevent supravalvular aortic stenosis in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Our overarching goal is to utilize biology-based mathematical models and advanced molecular imaging to dramatically decrease systemic toxicities while either maintaining or accelerating tumor control in preclinical models of breast cancer. Advances in systemic therapies have improved long-term survival in patients with locally-advanced breast cancer, however there has been a concomitant increase in the associated long- term side effects, including cognitive deficits and cardiotoxicity. We propose to develop the mathematical formalism, and then test this experimentally, that allows for systematically determining regimens that maximize tumor response and minimize side effects (as measured by PET imaging).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  As organisms age, their cells acquire broad changes in the epigenome, which are alterations around the genome that can impact cellular function. Our project seeks to understand how specific aspects of these epigenomic changes directly influence processes associated with aging. This could establish new methods to address a wide range of aging-related and other disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Ischemic Heart Disease (IHD) is the number one cause of death worldwide and is worsened by inflammation triggered via therapeutic reperfusion, which remains without medicinal intervention. As neutrophils are the first inflammatory cells recruited to the heart after injury and contribute to infarct expansion, we reasoned that dampening inflammatory activity in these cells would be cardioprotective. Our preliminary results indicate that YES Associated Protein (YAP) positively regulates neutrophil inflammatory function and that suppression of YAP during reperfusion may be a novel therapeutic target for cardioprotective intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative By developing a DNA polymerase that can copy and amplify DNA over very long (chromosome-sized) stretches, we will generate a tool for the research community, industry, and medicine that can be used to better create genomes from scratch, and read long stretches of DNA sequence information. The former application will abet the growing field of synthetic biology as it crafts new organisms, while the latter application should foment additional advances in Next Generation DNA sequencing. While there is ample activity in both spheres, the lack of an enzyme that can amplify long stretches of DNA is a hard ceiling that slows further advances.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Reinforcement learning Decision Making (RLDM), which encompasses a range of behaviors critical for survival, is impaired across various psychiatric disorders and symptoms. By acquiring a range of RLDM behavioral data from a large community sample with varying degrees of clinical symptomology, we aim to parse RL behavior into fine-grained mathematically defined constructs and build normative models to make predictions at individual- level. The proposed research aims to study RL behavior disorders at the individual level without parsing the clinical cohort, which could be the first step towards precision medicine by systematically mapping the heterogeneity of psychopathology based on behavior/transdiagnostic symptoms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Horizontal gene transfer is one of the main contributors to the worldwide spread of antibiotic resistance, with especially high prevalence in diverse and dense microbial communities, most notably the gut microbiome. This work will provide fundamental, mechanistic insights into the mechanisms underlying the spread of conjugative plasmids encoding antibiotic resistance. These insights have implications for predicting and controlling plasmid fates for medical and biotechnological applications. In particular, this work will significantly contribute to ongoing efforts to develop strategies of antibiotic treatments that efficiently eliminate pathogens with minimized risk of drug resistance spreading.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to understand the neural mechanisms by which expectations bias motivated behavior, and how they are overridden when an expectation is incorrect. We focus on the orbitofrontal cortex, which is believed to compute outcome expectations, and use electrocorticography to understand the dominant dynamics in OFC, as well as subregional variation, that produce biasing expectations and update them with new information. Together, this project will provide a uniquely holistic view of OFC function that will advance our understanding of expectation in mental models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The huge personal and societal costs of bereavement continue to grow as the US population ages and we face an ongoing pandemic. Using a combination of advanced genetic and cellular approaches, our proposal asks: What are the biological processes that are engaged in the brain when overcoming the loss of a loved one? Answering this question will provide new intervention targets for improving the negative health consequences associated with loss of a loved one and for treating pathological bereavement, such as Prolonged Grief Disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Synapses are the primary substrates driving information transfer throughout our nervous system. Defects in synaptic communication are associated with a vast number of neurological, neurodegenerative, and neuropsychiatric diseases including epilepsy, autism, schizophrenia, ALS, and Alzheimer’s Disease. While their importance is undeniable, the mechanisms that establish and modulate the diversity of synaptic strength remain enigmatic. This proposal seeks to reveal fundamental insights into what determines and adaptively modifies the diversity of presynaptic function at glutamatergic synapses in development and plasticity. Ultimately, this knowledge is necessary to understand the etiology of neural diseases resulting from synaptic dysfunction and develop effective therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative In this proposal, we make use of optogenetic and chemogenetic tools, in vivo calcium imaging, RNA-seq, viral-based circuit tracing, and genetic targeting techniques to dissect the neural circuits that control sleep behavior. By identifying novel sleep-inducing neurons in the brain, the work presented in this research proposal will lead to a mechanistic understanding of sleep behavior and may provide valuable information for developing new treatments for various human sleep disorders, such as insomnia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Noninvasive Neurally Adjusted Ventilatory Assist (NIV-NAVA) is an FDA approved technology that consistently synchronizes non-invasive respiratory support with infant respiratory drive.  We propose an unblinded, pragmatic, phase III randomized clinical trial in extremely preterm infants 240/7- 276/7 weeks gestational age to determine if NIV-NAVA, compared with non-synchronized nasal intermittent positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV), prevents extubation failure within 5 days (120 hours) of extubation from mechanical ventilation.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Relevance of the Proposed Studies to the VA Patient Care Mission: Age-related Hearing Loss (ARHL) and Age-related Vestibular Dysfunction (ARVD) impact large numbers of Veterans, reducing quality of life, job opportunities and increasing risk for other disorders ranging from falls to dementia. For many Veterans, ARHL and ARVD act on auditory and vestibular systems already impacted by noise exposure during their service. Studies are to develop safe, clinically relevant treatment(s) for ARHL, ARVD and noise-induced acceleration. Studies test mechanism-based interventions that can be started in mid-life and are well positioned for rapid translation to meet the challenges of aging in the Veteran population. Even before pharmacological treatments become clinically available, the knowledge of how noise can accelerate and increase ARHL and ARVD can lead to earlier and better diagnosis and use of available non-pharmacological interventions such as hearing aids for ARHL and physical therapy for ARVD that could increase quality of life and reduce risks for Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bacteriophages have profound impacts on microbial communities, ecosystems, and human health, while phage infection initiation is the least understood aspect in phage biology. We combine traditional genetic and molecular biology with cutting-edge imaging techniques to provide novel mechanistic insights into phage adsorption and genome transfer into the host cytoplasm. The proposed in vivo study also has implications on nanotechnology, antibacterial therapeutics, and development of novel DNA translocation systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative Care partners of persons with traumatic brain injury (TBI) are often faced with considerable physical and emotional stress resulting from their caregiver role; not surprisingly, this stress is associated with negative physical and mental health outcomes for both the care partner and the person for whom they provide care. Given this, interventions focused on improving the health-related quality of life (HRQOL) of these care partners will likely have positive downstream effects for the care recipient. The purpose of this study is to examine the efficacy of a personalized self-management intervention designed to promote care partner self-care; this intervention uses physical activity and sleep data collected using a Fitbit® and real-time self-reports of HRQOL collected via a mobile phone app, to provide care partners with personalized feedback via app alert four times per week.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Each year, over 1.5 million people survive sepsis and over one third transition to receive home health care (HHC) services. This study tests the effectiveness of the I-TRANSFER intervention which improves identification and communication of the sepsis survivor to HHC, provides early attention to prevent poor outcomes, and provides guidance on the implementation determinants discovered from a diverse sample of hospitals and home health agencies. The results of the study have the potential to inform clinical guidelines in home health care on a national scale and improve the recovery of the growing population of sepsis survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative A burgeoning hypothesis in Parkinson’s disease (PD) research is that PD begins in the gut, resulting in the subsequent alpha-synuclein (? S) aggregation and neurodegeneration. Furthermore, gut permeability, which enables leakage of microbial ligands from the gut microbiota into host tissues, and innate immune receptors, which recognize these ligands are widely associated with PD, although whether these factors directly initiate or exacerbate PD is unclear. In this proposal, I will investigate 1) the connections among microbial leakage, gut leakiness, and PD; 2) the role of innate immune receptors in PD pathogenesis; and 3) perform unbiased, genetic screens to identify novel host and bacterial PD factors, collectively increasing our understanding of PD initiation and progression and identification of novel therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The brain plays an integral role in the genesis of eating behaviors. However, the brain’s contribution to dysregulated eating behavior is not well understood during sensitive developmental periods such as adolescence, when excessive weight gain and obesity prevalence are a significant concern. In the proposed study, we will examine how the brain’s response to excess energy is related to dysregulated eating behaviors in adolescents with and without obesity with the overarching goal of providing a scientific basis to build new models of adolescent obesity risk and to test novel interventions for dysregulated eating behavior and obesity in developmentally vulnerable pediatric populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is a highly prevalent disease affecting 1 in 54 children in the US and risk to this disease is increased in individuals exposed to environmental chemicals such as BPA. Although mutations in the coding regions of genes affecting protein function have been identified in patients with ASD, the contribution of non-coding variants present in different individuals to ASD phenotypes and their interaction with the environment has not been explored. This study will identify non-coding genome variants that respond to BPA exposure by causing gene expression changes and alterations of neural cell fate similar to those observed in ASD patients, increasing our understanding of how chemicals in the environment may alter brain development in children with autism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Forty percent of emerging adults have overweight or obesity; however, emerging adults are underrepresented in traditional weight loss programs, drop-out at high rates, and have blunted weight loss outcomes. In this project, I propose to develop, iteratively adapt, and pilot test a behavioral weight loss intervention designed specifically to optimize feasibility, acceptability, and weight loss in emerging adults as well as be easily disseminable and implementable in college health service settings to improve intervention reach and access. This project will address a critical public health need and explore a novel treatment delivery model to improve weight status in emerging adults in the present that could reduce increasing obesity and related downstream health consequences in later adulthood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Narrative: Structural malformations of the face are common and often exhibit a large degree of morphologic variation; however, the mechanisms underlying variation are not known. Our objective is to examine the mechanistic basis for variable expressivity and penetrance that produce craniofacial malformations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  Neurons must constantly rebuild themselves as the membrane proteins that give rise to synaptic connectivity and electrical excitability are replaced. At the same time, brain circuits must be stable. The goals of this project are to understand how individual animals achieve robust function over time in the face of the need to respond flexibly to environmental perturbations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Because our understanding of hepatobiliary disease is incomplete, a significant number of children with biliary tree dysgenesis and liver disease have nondiagnostic genetic testing. The goal of this research proposal is to improve the diagnosis and care of children and adults with liver and biliary disease by better characterizing the genetic landscape of these conditions. To accomplish this goal, we will assemble and characterize a large cohort of patients with biliary and liver disease and apply a research pipeline for gene discovery and validation, with additional focus on MED12 as a novel biliary dysgenesis gene.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The loss or damage of sensory cells in the inner ear, specifically the outer hair cells (OHCs), is a critical cause of age-related and noise-induced hearing loss, which are now worldwide epidemics. This competitive renewal builds on our success in identifying transcription factors critical for the functional maturation and survival of OHCs to now define their role within the OHC genetic program. Successful completion of this research will: impact our understanding of inner ear sensory cell development and survival; advance research on the molecular basis of age-related hearing loss; and, inform the design of future therapeutic interventions such as hair cell regeneration therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Human hearing is characterized by high sensitivity and high frequency-selectivity. Unfortunately, this hearing function is fragile. A prominent signature of hearing loss is damage of outer hair cells, which can result in 40-60 dB of hearing loss. This project has Relevance to Public Health because it holds the promise to improve quality of life in individuals suffering hearing difficulty by identifying how outer hair cells operate to amplify small sounds. The project uses state-of-art measurement methods and computational simulations to quantify key unknowns related to the function of the outer hair cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our long-term goal is to understand the molecular and cellular events that underlie the formation and growth of unstable atherosclerotic plaques in blood vessels, which can cause heart attacks and strokes. These medical conditions represent the leading cause of death worldwide and are highly-relevant to the mission of the NIH. In particular, we are investigating how arterial inflammation and endothelial cell dysfunction contribute to the formation of vulnerable plaques with the goal of identifying new therapeutic targets to treat atherosclerosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The recently discovered checkpoint inhibitors for cancer immunotherapy that target T cell activation through blockage of PD1/PDL1 or CTLA4 have had amazing success in a subset of cancers but poor success in other cancer types. Thus, additional targets for therapeutic intervention are needed that boost the immune response and, in particular, ones that target the innate immune system. The focus of this proposal is to understand how expression of ST8Sia6 accelerates tumor growth through modulation of the immune response through Siglec- E, and to determine if ST8Sia6 downregulation on tumors renders them more susceptible to immune attack.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  Mutant KRAS ( K M ) is the most common oncogenic mutation of lung cancer. We determined that in  lung cancer KM establishes a critical dependency on fatty acid synthase (FASN), the enzyme that  catalyzes the synthesis of saturated long chain fatty acids.  In this proposal, we will test the innovative hypothesis that FASN exerts a pro-survival function by providing fatty acids to feed the Lands cycle, the main cellular process that deflect ferroptosis, a form of programmed cell death. We anticipate that our findings will provide unanticipated insights into KM-driven tumorigenesis, unravelling novel therapeutic venues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  This research is relevant to public health because women who have had an adverse pregnancy outcome, such as hypertensive disorders of pregnancy, preterm delivery, or small for gestational age, are more likely to develop heart disease later in life. The objective of this research is to determine whether there are differences in ultrasound markers of heart and blood vessel disease risk in women who had an adverse pregnancy outcome compared with those who did not, and to determine whether blood pressure and proteins measured during a woman’s first pregnancy are linked to risk of heart and blood vessel disease. Our study is very relevant to the NHLBI’s mission to improve maternal cardiovascular health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Faithful replication and maintenance of our genomes, which is vital to our survival, requires the action of complex multi-protein machinery that replicates our DNA and responds respond to aberrations in DNA that arise as a by-product of exposure to environmental toxins, sunlight, and even molecules produced naturally in cells. Defects in these protein machines lead to mutation and ultimately cancer and other diseases associated with genomic instabilities. Investigating the three-dimensional structure of the protein components of DNA replication and damage response machines and their interactions with each other and with the DNA will reveal intricate details of how replication and damage response occurs, what is defective in disease-associated mutant proteins, and open up new avenues for development of targeted therapies for patients suffering from maladies such as cancer that arise as a result of genomic instability.

PROJECT_TITLE: Integrative Structural Biology in DNA Replication and Damage Response

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Loss of mitochondria and oxidative capacity have been implicated in the development or progression of many diseases, from type 2 diabetes to cardiovascular diseases and skeletal muscle diseases. Understanding the mechanisms by which adipose cells respond to physiological signals, such as adrenergic stimulation, to build more mitochondria and higher capacity to oxidize nutrients, can present new ways for intervention in diseases associated with decreased oxidative capacity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Patients with metastatic non-small cell lung cancer undergo complex combinations of treatments including chemotherapy, immunotherapy, and radiation therapy; and while some patients have prolonged cancer control from therapy, others develop rapid progression. We propose to assess and monitor treatment response with positron emission tomography imaging and circulating immunologic biomarkers to improve patient outcomes by quickly detecting patients who are not benefiting from standard of care chemo-immunotherapy, and selecting for patients whose outcomes can be improved with the addition of radiation therapy. Development and validation of combined imaging and circulating biomarkers can support treatments that are adapted to the response of individual patients with metastatic non-small cell lung cancer and improve clinical outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Program Narrative Despite the critical role for memory B cells in establishing long-lived humoral immunity, the molecular programs that regulate their enhanced function and protective capabilities remain to be defined. Herein, we propose that epigenetic mechanisms serve as a molecular memory of prior states and underpins the enhanced recall responses of memory B cells. Using a robust set of assays and tools, we will define the epigenetic architecture of memory B cell subsets and identify pathways and transcription factors that ultimately could be used to improve immunity or treat autoimmune diseases where memory B cells are a component.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: There is considerable variation in response to the same antidiabetic therapy among individual diabetic patients. The proposed study aims to identify biomarkers to predict how an individual diabetic patient will respond to the glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor (GLP1R) agonist class of antidiabetic drugs. Availability of predictive biomarkers would enable physicians to prescribe therapies for each individual patient based on predictors of the magnitude of beneficial response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic pain – often arising from musculoskeletal injury, neurological disease, cancer, or autoimmune disease – affects ~100 million Americans. There is growing evidence that the plant Cannabis sativa has analgesic and anti‐inflammatory properties without the detrimental side effects seen by opioid use. Our studies will find the ingredients in Cannabis that reduce inflammation and chronic pain, which may help abate the nation's opioid epidemic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Public Health Relevance This research will benefit individuals who are deaf and use sign language as their primary language and will support the medical and rehabilitative organizations that serve this population. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a great clinical need for additional therapies for refractory Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD). In this proposal, we will study intestinal epithelial cells in mouse models and directly from patients to uncover more about the pathways involved in preserving intestinal epithelial integrity. The goal of this proposal is to identify potential methods of protecting intestinal epithelial cells from injury, rather than further suppressing the immune system, in patients with IBD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Intensive insulin therapy, which requires meticulous insulin dosing, every day and through the night, reduces cardiovascular disease in type 1 diabetes but is difficult for patients to maintain. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative The ultimate goal of this project is to engineer antibodies that we have previously identified that have broad and potent activity against most HIV viruses into ones that are active against all HIV viruses. After engineering the antibodies, we will test in a mouse model in the hope that these antibodies can eventually be used to prevent or treat HIV infection in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Relevance: Because this basic science proposal relates how different parts of the auditory cortex participate in sound perception, the work is relevant to increasing the understanding about how restricted brain damage such as that caused by stroke affects auditory function. The results of these studies will help us better understand how attention modulates auditory activity and thus has relevance for the spectrum disorders (that include, but are not limited to attention deficit disorder, dyslexia, etc). The results also could have relevance in helping to guide approaches to coding for hearing aids and cochlear implants since both neural coding and the ability to attend sounds are relevant for designing these devices.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: World-wide obesity rates pose a significant threat to public health, however pathways promoting weight loss are poorly understood. During lipolysis, adipocytes reuptake and oxidize a significant proportion of the released fatty acids. I propose to investigate a novel function of STAT3, required for this energy expending process, which occurs in non-thermogenic white adipocytes and therefore could be a powerful therapeutic target for achieving weight loss and winning the battle against obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE Mental illnesses often first appear in childhood and yet go mostly untreated until a serious disorder develops. This study will (a) implement ways to identify early mental health needs in children 4-12 years of age using free text notes entered into medical records, and (b) carry out a two-arm randomized trial to test if offering navigator support and video-based psychotherapy result in more mental health visits over a 6-month period of time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The triple negative breast cancer (TNBC), which is characterized by rapid growth, metastasis and recurrence, comprises about 15% of all breast cancers, and often regrows after primary treatment, leading to poor prognosis in TNBC patients. It is highly desired to develop an effective therapy for elimination of TNBC. Therefore, the combined antibody-drug conjugates (ADCs) that integrate the advantages of specific targeting and antibody- dependent cellular cytotoxicity of a novel tumor-specific monoclonal antibody and the direct cytotoxicity of the antibody-delivered payloads will be developed and characterized for TNBC treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Gene translocations often create fusion oncoproteins (FOs) that cause uncontrolled cell proliferation and oncogenesis in a wide variety of cancers. Our preliminary results show that gene fusions often create FOs that are abnormal transcription factors that we hypothesize drive oncogenesis by forming aberrant transcription centers, and other aberrant functional bodies through the process of liquid-liquid phase separation (LLPS). Our studies are addressing open questions regarding the oncogenic mechanisms associated with myriad FOs and may enable mechanistic interpretation of clinical genomics data on novel fusion oncogenes in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A challenge of targeting metabolic pathways in cancer is that tumor cells engage various adaptive mechanisms to suffice their metabolic demands or bypass their requirement. Using lymphoid malignancies, including acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) and aggressive B cell lymphoma, as models, we will determine the signaling and chromatin-modifying components that dictate ALL cells' adaptation to asparagine limitation and how glutamine/asparagine availability modulates oncogenic MYC function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: We propose to define the role of hepatic TAZ in the regulation of glucose and lipid homeostasis in normal and insulin resistant states. Deciphering the molecular mechanisms controlling metabolic regulation is crucial for the understanding of normal physiology and for developing new therapies for metabolic disorders. Therefore, we expect that our studies will advance our understanding of normal physiology as well as the pathogenesis of insulin resistance-associated metabolic disorders, which may uncover new opportunities for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE        Abnormal brain circuit structure and function underlies autism spectrum disorders (ASD), though it remains  unknown how this alters behavior. In this project, we will study a mouse model for a single gene cause of ASD.  We will use this model to elucidate novel biological mechanisms linking ASD risk genes to altered connectivity  of circuits that drive behaviors relevant to these disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Relevance Statement Adipose tissue fibrosis is an integral part of and likely to be a driving force for adipose tissue dysfunction and negative systemic metabolic consequences. Here, we want to focus on dermal adipose tissue, due to its easy accessibility, new genetic models that we have created and the established feature of almost uniform differentiation and de-differentiation of dermal adipocytes; a key aspect on the pathological road to fibrosis in all adipose tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The sensory neuron-specific mechanisms underlying mechanosensation in normal and pathological states are not well known. Piezo1 is a mechanosensitive cation channel that is a candidate mechanism in sensory neuron- mediated somatosensation. This proposal examines whether sensory neuron Piezo1 ion channels mediate peripheral tactile sensation and mechanical hypersensitivity following peripheral nerve injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because defects in endocytosis are at the heart of many diseases including cancer, neurodegeneration, and heart disease. Therefore, the proposed research plan to elucidate the fun- damental biophysical principles underlying endocytosis is relevant to the part of NIH's mission that seeks to develop fundamental knowledge that will mitigate the burden of human disease. Further, the proposed work studies an in- novative method to modulate endocytosis using substrate curvature, paving the way for the potential design of new strategies to treat multiple pathologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative: By defining the relationship between macrophage polarization and protective effector function and how this relationship is regulated, this proposal has the potential to identify new therapeutic targets to control fungal growth. This approach should address the decades-long failure to make major improvements in the outcome of PcP. The goal of this project is directly responsive to the NIH mission statement of the need to generate basic science data that can be developed into translational studies designed to improve patient care. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Low levels of oxygen (hypoxia) within a tumor is a barrier to effective therapy with radiation and immune checkpoint blockade. We have developed some new drug like compounds that can reduce the consumption of oxygen within the tumor and reduce hypoxia. We now propose to test these in model tumors to see if they sensitize to treatment with radiation or PD1 blockade.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Somatic mutations arising in clonal hematopoiesis and myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS) are a major public health problem characterized by dysfunctional hematopoietic stem and progenitor cells, abnormal blood production, and a risk of progression to acute leukemia. Deletions or mutations of CUX1, encoding a highly- conserved transcription factor, are recurrent in clonal hematopoiesis and MDS. We aim to understand the mechanism by which CUX1 levels regulate hematopoietic development with the goal of informing new interventions to improve the quality of life for patients with these genetic changes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this proposal, we will apply adductomics to investigate environmental risk factors for breast cancer in the Sister Study cohort. Adduct profiles will be quantified in plasma from 1,800 incident breast cancer cases and a random sample of 1,800 Sister Study participants. We will also perform secondary analyses to investigate associations between adducts and environmental exposures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While an important focus of Transfusion Medicine has been to maintain immune compatibility of blood components as well as the safe and appropriate use of blood products, the expansive growth in knowledge of blood cell biology has correspondingly increased options for investigation. Transfusion Medicine scientists and specialists now direct the generation of novel blood component products and the translation of cell-based therapies. Our postdoctoral training program is tailored to meet the recognized need for scientific training of individuals to further advance knowledge and clinical use of hematopoietic cellular therapies to treat diseases.
