IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Marked alterations of mitochondria have been observed in liver cells of human α1-antitrypsin deficiency (ATD) patients and the PiZ mouse model of ATD, leading to speculation that mitochondrial dysfunction is at least part of the pathogenesis of severe ATD liver disease. Based on that consideration and our new preliminary data, we now believe that mitochondrial impairment is a key part of the pathobiology of ATD liver disease in two ways, impaired liver cell energy metabolism and reduced autophagic response, and, therein, that mitochondrial function is a very appealing target for potential therapeutic interventions. In this grant we propose to study the effects of ATZ accumulation on mitochondrial function to better understand the mechanism by which liver is damaged and to investigate whether mitochondrial function can be targeted for therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: The 2013–2016 Ebola virus (EBOV) disease (EVD) epidemic was orders of magnitude larger than any other EVD outbreak. A mutation in the Ebola virus, GP- A82V, was found to dominate the outbreak and to increase infectivity in surrogate assays for the full virus. The experiments here will use genetic, biophysical, structural, and immunologic approaches to better understand the structure of the GP- A82V protein and the effect of the mutant on replication of full virus. These experiments are expected to help us to better understand how the Ebola virus replicates and, in turn, to develop new therapies that block this deadly virus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We use visual shape information to evaluate objects in the world: to determine their identity, utility, familiarity and value. The project will advance our understanding of how visual shape information is processed in the cerebral cortex by investigating the mechanisms involved using innovative tools. Knowledge of these cortical mechanisms is essential for understanding normal visual function, and for developing therapeutic strategies for disorders of form vision such as visual agnosia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: The Opportunities in Genomics Research (OGR) Program is designed to increase the number of students from underrepresented groups who pursue PhDs in genome science and related fields. OGR runs a summer undergraduate research program and an academic year post-baccalaureate research program. Through a suite of educational activities, these programs seek to train students to think critically and to write and speak effectively about their research project and science in general, and ultimately prepare them to gain acceptance to and succeed in top biomedical PhD programs nationwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Glioblastoma (GBM) is universally lethal, virtually always recurring and we are investigating how one of the treatments for GBM, radiation, may ultimately contribute to this recurrence. We have found that radiation can cause tumor cells to become blood vessel cells. We will test the hypothesis that these newly formed vascular cells contribute to GBM progression and determine the mechanisms whereby this vascular reprogramming occurs in experimental animals and in human tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: A thorough understanding of the mechanisms that regulate the functions of retinal glial cells is crucially important to the development of new therapies to treat sight-threatening diseases of the eye. Retinal Müller glia are known to have the potential to become neurogenic progenitor cells. Identification and understanding the mechanisms that regulate the ability of Müller glia to reprogram into proliferating, neurogenic progenitors is key to developing new therapies to treat degenerative diseases. This proposal seeks to identify the important factors and pathways that control the ability of Müller glia to become proliferating progenitors and produce new functional neurons.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Disorders and disruptions to visual perception from disease and traumatic injury lead to disabilities affecting a significant population of the United States. The proposed project will use a genetic model system to study the cell-circuit mechanisms for normal feature-based visual perception, as well as how deficits are caused and ameliorated. The proposed research is expected to facilitate broader understanding of normal visual function, thereby highlighting dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mesenteritis is an inflammatory disease of gut mesentery; however, its cause remains unknown. We will assess the role of macrophages which reside in serous membrane of gut mesentery and their mechanism in mediating mesenteritis induced by gut inflammation. Our findings will increase our understanding of the role of membrane-associated macrophages during mesenteritis and potentially lead to the development of treatment for mesenteritis associated with gut inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project narrative Cerebral cavernous malformations (CCMs) are common neurovascular lesions in which the severity of the disease is highly variable, suggesting that environmental factors may act as disease modifiers. We have discovered that hypoxic conditions worsen vascular lesions during CCM disease. We propose a new paradigm that hypoxia signaling triggered by the environment (e.g., high altitude) or pathology (e.g., obstructive sleep apnea, chronic lung disease) promote CCM lesion development and may represent a significant risk factor for brain bleedings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Feeding has long been known to be controlled by neuronal circuits in the hypothalamus, however, we have shown that changes in the mitochondria in fat cells can also lead to increased food intake. We have also shown that the type of fats in the diet can drive increased food intake. Here we will determine how mitochondrial dynamics in fat cells and hypothalamic feeding circuits interacts with dietary fat composition to influence caloric intake.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Project Narrative: Children from food insecure households are at higher risk for overweight, obesity, and other chronic disease and more research is needed to identify and characterize individual, behavioral, and environmental factors that underlie these relationships. This study will examine a novel behavioral phenotype, sensitization to repeated intake of snack food, and its relationship with food insecurity, body weight and weight change over time in a cohort of adolescents from moderate to low income families. We will also examine the impact of family dynamics of food insecurity on the relationship between sensitization and weight change over time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Existing national surgical quality improvement programs have not significantly updated their processes for data collection, data analysis, or providing feedback to stakeholders in decades. Alternative strategies that could be implemented within quality improvement programs’ current infrastructure could make these programs more timely, efficient, and effective. This mixed-methods proposal will evaluate the extent to which such alternative approaches could be used to improve existing national surgical quality improvement programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative and Public Health Relevance Statement Silencing large regions of the genome is essential for proper cell function and these heterochromatic regions are organized at the nuclear periphery. A diagnostic marker of tumor severity and patient outcome are distortions to the size and shape of the nucleus, termed pleomorphism. The research program proposed aims to develop a fundamental understanding of heterochromatin formation at the nuclear envelope, which will provide tangible targets for cancer therapies that aim to restore proper regulation of gene expression and nuclear morphology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE (PUBLIC RELEVANCE) Allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplantation (HCT) is a potentially curative therapy for many inherited and malignant diseases whose applicability has been impeded by the development of one of its most serious complication, chronic graft versus host disease (cGVHD). Unfortunately, there is no validated blood test for predicting the risk of developing cGVHD. Strategies that identify and validate biomarkers for risk of cGVHD occurrence will allow for personalized therapies that will be more efficient if introduced early in the course of the disease in many patients with hematological cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Because of the problems associated with recurrent ocular infection, reducing establishment of latency and reactivation should be a major goal of controlling ocular HSV-1 infection. We now plan to determine if suppression of CD80 by HSV-1 ICP22 gene affects virus replication in the eye, eye disease and latency- reactivation. We also plan to evaluate the negative effect of CD80 on eye disease using a combination of recombinant ICP22 viruses, knockout mice and transgenic mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The importance of myelination is highlighted by the devastating neurological symptoms that accompany diseases such as leukodystrophies and multiple sclerosis. Despite myelin’s essential function in maintaining the health of the CNS, the precise molecular mechanisms that regulate its formation have not been fully elucidated. Successful completion of this proposal will help uncover key molecular mechanisms that drive CNS myelination, potentially leading to new therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: CHARLES R. DREW UNIVERSITY OF MED & SCI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE /RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Despite the prevention and treatment efforts of the past 30 years, Latino men who have sex with men (MSM) continue to be disproportionately impacted by HIV nationally, and is particularly a problem in Los Angeles, which is a predominantly Latino minority city. Yet a powerful cultural source of motivation for behavior change has been underutilized: the family. The long-term goal of this K01 is for Dr. del Pino to become an independent investigator and national thought leader (1) to expand our understanding of the impact of family relationships on Latino MSM and how to include them in the development and testing of HIV biomedical interventions and (2) to address HIV and other health disparities in diverse sexual and gender minority communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In contemporary practice for people with HIV, type 2 diabetes mellitus, obesity, and food insecurity (insufficient access to enough food for an active, healthy life) are major threats to health. The proposed research program will significantly advance our understanding of how to best address food insecurity in the context of diabetes management for people with HIV, by testing an innovative medically tailored meal delivery + lifestyle intervention for individuals with food insecurity, diabetes, and HIV. This intervention has the potential to improve health and reduce the impact of food insecurity among people with HIV and diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: This proposal develops an acellular therapy for the in vivo regeneration of the mandibular condyle cartilage of the temporomandibular joint using a novel multi-layer scaffold design and biomaterials. The novel scaffold design will be used to recapitulate the native tissue architecture. Furthermore, we have developed a novel clinically relevant injury model for the TMJ in goats, which is used in the proposed studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: Cataract is the primary cause of blindness in the world and, with surgery as the most common treatment, it costs the US healthcare system billions of dollars each year. Major lens membrane proteins, AQP0 and Lim2 are essential for lens transparency and an understanding of the roles that these proteins play in cataract formation will allow therapies to be developed to prevent, treat or delay its onset. This proposal focuses on structural analysis of these two lens membrane proteins using advanced mass spectrometry techniques with the goal of elucidating the role that protein-protein and protein-lipid interactions play in cataract development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: This proposal centers on the impact of atypical, shortened (s) TDP43 isoforms in the pathogenesis of frontotemporal dementia (FTD) and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). The studies described here will uncover the prevalence of sTDP43 deposition in sporadic and familial FTD/ALS, illustrate downstream consequences of sTDP43 accumulation for RNA homeostasis, and determine the contribution of sTDP43 to neurodegeneration in FTD/ALS disease models. Our aim is to highlight a heretofore-undiscovered disease mechanism responsible for neurodegeneration in TDP43-related FTD/ALS, paving the way for effective therapeutic approaches that prevent sTDP43 deposition.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative Individuals with diverse backgrounds, behaviors, health issues, exposures and dietary habits may have different metabolic responses to food components and patterns of eating with important health and wellness implications. To identify predictive characteristics for specific nutritional responses with health risks or benefits to the individual, this study proposes to capitalize on the unprecedented scope and scale of the All of Us Research Program by adding dietary response assessment data in an ancillary sub-cohort, and by utilizing technologies for multi-omics, microbiome, and wearable devices. A prototype challenge meal and three distinct dietary patterns are proposed with the expectation that responses to both macro- and micro-nutrients in a diverse cohort will reflect the distribution of physiologic response phenotypes in the population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Project Narrative The studies proposed in this application assess mechanisms by which the hormone amylin suppresses food intake and body weight by influencing macronutrient intake, with particular focus on its actions in the ventral tegmental area (VTA), a key nucleus in the brain important for feeding and other motivated behaviors. Understanding the integrated mechanisms by which amylin acts in the brain to promote negative energy balance may shed light onto novel mechanisms of action for energy balance control, and thus may provide insight into novel pharmacological targets and strategies for the treatment of obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Heart failure is the most expensive medical problem in the United States, and a major cause of death and disability. While the disease is less common in children, the clinical consequences are similarly severe. Emerging experimental evidence and epidemiologic data suggest that the pediatric heart failure population is distinctly different from adult patients. However, the treatment paradigms remain similar, based almost entirely on data derived from adults. This application will address potential novel treatments for pediatric heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Most melanomas fail to anti-PD1 because of lack of immune cells within the tumors. Our proposed study will look at how a newly identified pathway on tumor vasculature comprises a resistant mechanism to limit immune cell infiltration into melanoma, with the aim of targeting this pathway to improve melanoma therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project narrative TDP-43 aggregation is a common feature of many neurodegenerative diseases and myopathies. In this proposal I will isolate TDP-43 aggregates from skeletal muscle and test the hypothesis that muscle-derived TDP-43 aggregates can be transmitted in a retrograde manner to the brain. The proposed experiments have the potential to change the current understanding of the spread of pathology in several neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Histological transformation from lung adenocarcinoma (LUAD) to small cell lung cancer (SCLC) and subsequent diversification into more aggressive SCLC subtypes, are examples of neuroendocrine lineage plasticity, a process that promotes metastasis and treatment resistance in lung cancer. This proposal uses 1) single-cell sequencing in patient tumors of combined LUAD/SCLC histology and 2) functional experiments in preclinical models of SCLC transformation to identify transcriptomic and epigenetic changes driving lineage plasticity. These molecular drivers may identify a novel class of drug targets that ablate lineage plasticity, with therapeutic implications in not just lung cancer but also any cancer type where small cell transformation may arise.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Relevance: HGSC is the most lethal form of ovarian cancer and remains largely incurable. CCNE1amp HGSC has a particularly poor prognosis, as it fails to respond to platinum-based therapy. By developing and characterizing sophisticated new mouse and human models of CCNE1amp HGSC, we hope to develop new therapeutic strategies for this deadly disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Although lifetime prevalence of schizophrenia is equal between sexes, adolescent onset schizophrenia is almost twice as common in males. Dysfunction in prefrontal cortex is a key feature of the disease, and prefrontal cortical circuits develop late in adolescence. This project will examine how microglia, a resident immune cell in the brain that are sexually dimorphic, shape prefrontal circuitry and cognition in typical adolescent development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The ultimate cause of most breast cancer-related deaths is metastasis, the spread of cancer to distant organs. Recent research indicates that in breast cancer, as well as many other tumor types, circulating clusters of tumor cells are associated with therapy resistance, widespread metastases, and significantly worse prognosis. By learning more about these micrometastases, this proposal seeks to identify molecular vulnerabilities that can be used to eradicate them, thereby extending survival in patients with metastatic breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Progressive multiple sclerosis is a common, debilitating disease that currently has no effective treatments. Nanoparticle drug delivery methods capable of reinvigorating glial cells’ ability to produce myelin are promising, but the major limiting factor is the inability to effectively cross the blood-brain barrier to target the right cells. We have developed a strategy to determine how our own natural bioparticles reach these cells, to engineer these abilities into a remyelination-stimulating drug delivery system.

PHR: Project Narrative - Relevance  Using the Pavlovian fear conditioning paradigm, the proposed experiments outlined in this document will expand the current literature on the physiological underpinnings of fear memory storage. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: There is a critical need for new linker technology for antibody-drug conjugates (ADCs) in order to avoid off-target payload release that drives dose-limiting toxicity. Herein, we propose the optimization and evaluation of novel ADC linkers that are cleaved by legumain. We will optimize the cleavage rate and stability of this linker, demonstrate its efficacy in models of pancreatic cancer, and establish its safety profile in comparison to existing ADC technology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Trypsins are proteins that mediate disease processes in cancer and pancreatitis. More selective inhibitors are needed to target trypsins in order to study the roles of these proteins in diseases and as a stepping stone to developing better drugs to treat these diseases. In this project, we will develop highly selective trypsin inhibitors, along with innovative new methods for studying interactions between proteins that will be applicable to unraveling many disease processes and developing new drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The causative relationships between global transcriptomic dysregulation in Down Syndrome (DS) and the observed pathological phenotypes in brain cells as well as the development of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) pathology remains unclear. In the current application, we will investigate whether downregulated in trisomy brain expressed X-linked/transcription elongation factor A (SII) (BEX/TCEAL) genes on X chromosome contribute to the global transcriptomic alterations and neurodevelopmental and neurodegenerative cellular phenotypes in DS. Thus, we will assess whether we can mitigate cellular and molecular phenotypes in DS-and AD-related pathology by correcting the dysregulation of the X-chromosome-linked genes in DS-derived cortical spheroids.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  The locomotor central pattern generator (CPG) is thought to be a set of neurons responsible for the generation of rhythmic neuronal activity. Proper assembly and function of the locomotor CPG is essential for the development of normal locomotor rhythm and pattern and therefore, essential to the survival of the animal. We have recently reported that ventral spinocerebellar tract (VSCT) neurons are necessary and sufficient for locomotor behavior. This proposal aims to elucidate the physiological properties, connectivity, and function of VSCT neurons both during development and adulthood using mouse models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic pain has a staggering economic cost and causes huge suffering to individuals. Once pain is chronic it is very hard to reverse and, hence, the best strategy to prevent chronic pain is early identification and treatment of high-risk individuals. This application aims to identify structural gray and white matter biomarkers of risk and resilience to pain chronification after the onset of low-back pain by testing specific hypotheses based on existing knowledge of chronic pain and the brain while at the same time addressing the influence of sex and types of clinical presentations (i.e., presence or absence of sciatica).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The development of powerful biomarkers, measuring amyloid deposition, tau accumulation, and neurodegeneration, has provided important insights into the pathophysiology of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and AD-related dementias. Still, we do not understand why some individuals are able to resist pathology while others are more susceptible to cognitive decline. In this proposal, we will investigate two aims with the overall goals of (1) advancing magnetic resonance elastography technology in order to (2) assess the impact of biomechanics, an understudied facet of brain structure, on the pathology-cognition relationship.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Although Black men in the United States are disproportionately impacted by diabetes and experience incarceration at very high rates, there is limited research to date on best strategies to improve health outcomes for this population. To address this gap in knowledge, we propose to study MANAGe-DM, a novel nurse case management intervention comprised of three components: diabetes education/skills training, basic needs navigation, and health system navigation in improving glycemic control among Black men with type 2 diabetes with recent release from incarceration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Our overarching objective is to increase engagement in oncofertility care by female and male adolescent and young adult cancer patients at cancer diagnosis, in order to improve their future fertility and quality of life. Through a stepped wedge cluster randomized trial, we will evaluate the effectiveness of three scalable, telehealth interventions (a smart electronic health record screen and referral, telehealth oncofertility counseling, and telehealth financial navigation) in adult and pediatric oncology settings. We will also study how the intervention is implemented to inform future scaling up.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative According to the American Academy of Pediatrics, approximately half of US children experience significant sleep issues, despite the critical importance of sleep to a child’s physical, cognitive, and behavioral development. Exposure to some types of endocrine-disrupting chemicals such as perfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) have been shown to be associated with sleep outcomes. Our study would be the first to explore the link between individual and mixtures of PFAS during pregnancy and child sleep problems, disturbance, and impairment at ages 2, 3, and 4 years using existing data from a pregnancy cohort study in Illinois.

PHR: Project Narrative  Our project focuses on the respiratory health of young Mexican American adults living in an agricultural community for whom we have collected extensive information since their mothers were pregnant. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement (Project Narrative) In order to better understand the composition of human white adipose tissue, we performed single nucleus RNA sequencing, which allowed us to collect information about individual cell types within this complex tissue. We found several distinct types of adipocytes, some of which are associated with body weight and risk of type 2 diabetes (T2D). Here we will identify which factors predispose to the development of one adipocyte type over another, with the goal of finding targets for treatments that can ameliorate metabolic diseases like T2D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Currently, there are over 5.7 million Alzheimer’s disease (AD) patients in the United States, and nearly two-thirds of the AD patients are postmenopausal women who have lost the neuroprotective effects of estrogens. We have synthesized and characterized a non-steroidal estrogenic ligand, STX that selectively targets the CNS and is neuroprotective against amyloid toxicity in a mouse model of AD. In the proposed studies we will isolate the STX receptor using photo-crosslinking and click chemistries and confirm its identity via in vivo CRISPR mutagenesis studies, which will augment the development of STX as a novel therapeutic for treating postmenopausal women and AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) is a leading cause of blood clotting and is triggered by abnormal antibodies that activate immune cells and thereby damage blood vessels. This proposal investigates a natural mechanism by which enzymes convert harmful molecules released from dying cells into a substance called adenosine that protects blood vessels from inflammation. The goal of this work is to harness these protective pathways to protect against the devastating effects of APS in patients.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) affects 1 in 44 children, but our understanding of the genetics of ASD remains limited. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Public Health Relevance The molecular mechanisms responsible for neuropsychological impairment in HIV patients are not easily inferred with conventional high-throughput analysis methods. To investigate the molecular mechanisms behind the interactions of HIV and methamphetamine (METH), this interdisciplinary project will profile gene expression at the single cell level in key brain regions relevant to the effects of persistent HIV infection and substance use disorder (SUD) in a small animal model of neuroHIV in a behavioral paradigm of voluntary intravenous METH self-administration. We will bring to bear computational methods to elucidate the genes (master regulator genes) driving the altered gene expression, which will provide a framework for new testable hypotheses on the mechanisms underlying the neuropathogenesis of the increased neuroinflammation, neurodegeneration and compulsivity to take METH in the context of METH abuse that can be targeted therapeutically to improve neuropsychological functioning in people with HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: RELEVANCE Black Americans are at nearly twice the risk for Alzheimer’s disease and Related dementias (ADRD) compared to non-Hispanic White Americans; yet they are underrepresented in research. As a result, our scientific understanding of ADRD may not generalize to Black populations. This project will investigate the prevailing theory of Alzheimer’s disease, the Amyloid hypothesis, testing if it holds up in a group of Black participants, and we will also examine recruitment and retention strategies using a scientific approach to understand what works and why.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Stroke is a leading cause of significant, long-term disability; yet no medical therapies exist to improve recovery. Utilizing bioengineering methods, such as biomaterials and stem cell scaffolds, to interact with the nervous system provides new approaches to (1) improve functional stroke recovery and (2) understand recovery mechanisms. Our proposed project utilizes conductive polymers to electrically modulate stem cells and identify recovery pathways from stem cell biology to enhance the brain’s own recovery mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative For the brain to function properly, neurons must form active and efficient circuitry during development by refining synaptic connections, where active neuronal connections stay (maintained) while inactive ones leave (eliminated). We will determine how neuronal connections decide to stay or leave by characterizing the molecular determinants of the refinement. Defects in synapse refinement have been implicated in various neurological and psychiatric disorders, and thus, our work will yield novel insights into the pathophysiology and treatment of such disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Summary/Abstract In the US, about 1.7 million Healthcare-Associated Infections (HAls) occur in hospitals each year, resulting in 99,000 deaths and an estimated $20 billion in healthcare costs. According to previous reports, as much as one third of HAI cases can be attributed to environmental surfaces, namely “high touch” surfaces (e.g., bed rails, machine buttons, equipment), in hospitals. Self-sanitizing coatings, i.e., antimicrobial surfaces, are an ideal theoretical solution for eliminating persistent pathogens; however there has been no commercially available antimicrobial material which can achieve high biocidal efficacy against pathogens with other necessary attributes, such as easy to apply, broad material compatibility, no resistance development to pathogens, and cost-effective. HaloFilm™ is a breakthrough product. HaloFilm is a spray-on product that when dried leaves a thin transparent film on a surface. The film is a polymer composed of one repeating unit with a functional group that adheres to a surface, and another functional repeating unit that stabilizes the chlorine. HaloFilm turns the surface into a chlorine battery so when it is used with a chlorine-based disinfectants it will allow the surface to be covered with the same level of chlorine found in a pool. HaloFilm is the only product that can pass EPA testing protocols as the supplemental residual antimicrobial coatings and films against bacteria and an enveloped virus surrogate for SARS-CoV-2. In fact, the EPA tested 20 of commercial products and none of the spray-on products achieved the 3-log reduction against Phi6 that HaloFilm achieved. HaloFilm is Halomine Inc.’s first product and is protected by exclusively licensed patents from Auburn University and Cornell University and will be brought to market in 2023 in collaboration with Diversey, a $2.7 billion global hygiene and infection control company. In this Phase II we will continue development of our product category by deepening our understanding of its efficacy against pathogens that are problematic in healthcare environments, extend HaloFilm’s use by developing a wipe based HaloFilm product, and investigate potential for an optimum companion product that can maximize biocidal efficacy of the product in service.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE It is not clear why binge-eating episodes, and often other behaviors in people with binge-eating disorder (BED), are both impulsively initiated and inflexibly persistent, or why some people with BED binge eat more frequently than others. This study will examine whether abnormal connectivity within and between brain circuits during decision-making could contribute to hallmark features of BED and promote more severe forms of this disabling and often chronic disorder. Data from this project will inform a more precise explanatory model of BED symptoms and identify circuit-based targets for new treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sickle cell disease affects 100,000 people and 2,000 newborns each year; 50% of these children have a developmental deficit (>2 SD) before the age of 3. Early identification of developmental deficit supports timely intervention, but children with sickle cell disease are grossly underdiagnosed and undertreated. The goal of the proposed study is to determine the incidence and severity of developmental deficit at 9, 18 and 30 months of age among children with sickle cell disease and test a 12-month, home-based caregiver intervention with this disproportionately affected population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer remains the second leading cause of death in the United States, but most advanced cancer patients do not understand key information about their disease well enough to help them make informed healthcare decisions. The proposed study will address this public health issue by examining how psychological and physiological aspects of stress and anxiety may interfere with patients' accurate understanding, then by adapting and testing a stress management intervention to address these factors. The long-term goal of this work is to reduce stress-related barriers to informed decision-making, in order to improve quality of life and end-of-life care among those with cancer.

PROJECT_TITLE: Leveraging behavioral science to improve patient understanding of advanced cancer

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  GABAergic interneurons play key roles in the development and maintenance of the neocortex. This proposal will determine how interneurons that express somatostatin (SST-INs) contribute to the maturation of circuits underlying spontaneous and sensory-evoked neuronal activity in mouse visual cortex. We expect our findings to provide important insights into the cellular underpinnings of cortical development and visual processing by the brain.

PHR: Neurotropic alphaherpesviruses are responsible for a range of human diseases including cold sores, blindness and birth defects. This proposal dissects the mechanisms of alphaherpesvirus assembly and trafficking within the nervous system, events that are essential for the progression and spread of infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Assistive robots have the potential to enhance individual autonomy, reduce human burden, and lower healthcare costs associated with mild cognitive impairment, Alzheimer’s dementia, and mobility impairments for older adults, family care partners, and professional caregivers. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Excess adiposity is independently associated with recurrence risk and death in hormone receptor-positive breast cancer, but, among non-Hispanic Black women and hormone-receptor negative breast cancer cases, associations are less clear. We will test the central hypothesis that adipose tissue depots (visceral vs. subcutaneous), measured using computed tomography scans, have differing associations with adipokine and adipokine receptor gene expression profiles and related gene signatures in the breast tumor microenvironment, which can be used to develop outcome predictive models. This high impact study will advance the field by yielding new data on how adipose tissue distribution impacts (1) gene expression profiles in the breast tumor microenvironment and (2) breast cancer outcomes, with an emphasis on the interplay among race and ethnicity and tumor subtype.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project Narrative  Innate immunity plays a critical role in nearly all infectious and autoimmune diseases, and is very similar in nearly all animals. Thus, we propose to investigate the innate immune system of the fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster and how it responds to bacterial infection. This research may have a direct and profound impact on continuing efforts to modulate the immune response in mosquitoes, in order to reduce the transmission of vector-borne diseases such as malaria, West Nile Virus, or Zika. In addition, discoveries from this research have direct relevance to similar innate immune pathways in humans, which will also be investigated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ovarian cancer is a major public health issue and is often diagnosed in later stages, resulting in an increased risk of death. Extracellular vesicles are nanoscale particles that circulate throughout bodily fluids and are released by all cells, and their cargo may indicate early signs of ovarian cancer or inform better treatment strategies. The proposed training and research will create improved methods for characterizing and classifying extracellular vesicles to improve patient outcomes by developing ultrasensitive detection devices and machine learning analytical tools.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Shoulder tendon tears are a common cause of shoulder pain and disability and after surgery the repaired tendon often does not heal. In this pilot study, men with low sex hormone levels will be randomly assigned to receive sex hormone therapy or placebo pills while healing from tendon repair surgery in their shoulder. Sex hormone therapy increases sex hormone levels, and the investigators will test whether these increased sex hormone levels show promise in improving tendon healing and patient shoulder function and pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Family caregivers and home care aides interact to provide care for older adults living with Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD), but their relationship is often made difficult due to gaps in information, misalignment of role expectations, lack of shared understanding of each other’s roles in home care, and preferences regarding daily activities and routines. The goal of this proposal is to develop and refine a home care role and preference guide to improve information sharing between family caregivers of older adults living with ADRD and home care aides. The proposal will support the career development of Dr. Chanee Fabius who aims to conduct embedded pragmatic clinical trials (ePCTs) directed at testing interventions, policies and programs in real world settings to better support the home care workforce and improve care quality and quality of life among vulnerable older adults receiving services and their family caregivers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE It is largely recognized that to best study and understand the health needs of a diverse population, it is important to have a diverse group of health scientists and researchers. However, many talented potential researchers fail to make it into biomedical research because they did not have access to adequate research opportunities in college. Here we propose a two-year post-baccalaureate program targeted at such individuals to help prepare them to enter and succeed in a biomedical research career.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Atrazine is an agricultural herbicide widely used in the Midwestern United States. Atrazine is the most common contaminant of potable water supplies in the United States and is an endocrine disrupting chemical that targets the neuroendocrine and neurotransmitter systems. This study will investigate the kisspeptin system as the master regulator connecting adverse health outcomes observed following developmental atrazine exposure along the multiple endocrines axes and neurotransmission systems for translation to human health risk.

This new training program builds on a strong legacy and ongoing commitment to vaccine development and evaluation at Cincinnati Children’s Hospital, and will meet this important need.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Viruses related to smallpox continue to be a threat to global public health, especially because most people are no longer being vaccinated against smallpox. Here, we plan to study how infectious poxvirus particles are assembled and released from cells. We believe our work will provide new information that will aid in the development of new treatments for these viruses and in improving the ways in which harmless forms of these viruses can be used for cancer therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Enteric infections are a common cause of dysbiosis, and have been implicated as an environmental factor in onset and flare of IBD. Our preliminary data has identified enteric infection in nearly 30% of IBD flares, with the most common pathogens including Clostridioides difficile, Escherichia coli, and norovirus. This study will determine the clinical and molecular impact of specific enteric pathogens on the course of IBD to directly improve IBD outcomes and further elucidate mechanisms of pathogen-associated dysbiosis underlying chronic gastrointestinal inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDA) is characterized by extensive desmoplasia caused by different cancer-associated fibroblast (CAF) populations. As a major source of fibroblasts in other pathological conditions such as wound healing, peritoneal fibrosis and surgical adhesions, mesothelial cells have been historically neglected as a potential functional constituent of the PDA microenvironment. This project aims to investigate the contribution of mesothelial cells to CAF formation and the function of mesothelial-fibroblastic transition in PDA, which will elucidate a novel mesothelial cell-CAF system and has the potential to result in the identification of novel strategies to target CAFs in PDA.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: EDITH NOURSE  ROGERS MEMORIAL VETERANS HOSPITAL
PHR: Surveillance of Modifiable Social Determinants of Health for Prioritizing Wraparound Supports 60% of Veterans in Veterans Treatment Courts (VTCs) have a co-occurring mental health and opioid use disorder (OUD), thereafter called COD. Those Veterans are at risk for opioid overdose (OOD) but have less engagement of medications for OUD (MOUD) and other OUD treatments than other Veterans, resulting in unemployment and homelessness - predictors of reoffending. Many Veterans in VTCs, particularly those with an OUD have multiple social determinants of health (SDOH) issues that need to be addressed simultaneously. In this application, we will develop and test SoS-MISSION, a dashboard which flags unmet social needs of justice-involved Veterans at high risk of MOUD discontinuation and OOD.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Family caregivers frequently provide transfer assistance to Veterans with mobility impairments to facilitate the completion of essential daily tasks like bathing, toileting, and getting in/out of bed. However, assisted transfers are known to be one of the most strenuous activities leading to back and shoulder pain and injury to the caregiver and potential harm to the Veteran if not performed correctly. Recently, a tool called the Caregiver Assisted Transfer Technique Instrument (CATT) was developed to assess the quality of the transfer techniques used by informal caregivers. The tool is designed to identify deficits in technique that if corrected could reduce the risk of injuries to both the caregiver and their care recipients. The goal of this project is to determine the reliability and validity of the CATT and test its ability to improve the transfer technique of caregivers when used as an assessment and training tool.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Amputation is one of the most cited injuries of recent conflicts, and the technology of advanced prosthetics have received substantial attention. Prosthetic arms are often uncomfortable which is generally attributable to the fit and comfort of sockets and harnesses and are not worn primarily for this reason. This project is focused on an innovative new transradial socket textile-based design inspired by advanced athletic shoe technology. This study will improve upon and investigate the validity of an innovative new transradial socket and harness design with a hybrid polymer and textile-based design derived from advanced athletic shoe technology. The system creates a dynamic and secure attachment with a combination of two lacing systems. These lacing systems lengthen and shorten flexible hinges at the elbow, maintaining a secure attachment throughout the range of motion and accounting for volume changes.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Obstructive Sleep Apnea (OSA) is common in military Veterans, who may not completely to treatment with Positive Airway Pressure (PAP) and experience persistent sleepiness and depression. A growing body of literature in animal and human models suggests that the sleep and respiratory disturbances commonly seen in OSA, can promote shifts in circadian rhythms ultimately leading to misalignment between sleep-wake rhythms and the internal clock. Targeting the circadian disturbance with chronotherapeutic interventions, such as Bright Light Therapy, may improve symptoms that most affect daily functioning andquality of life, ultimately preventing the downstream effects of OSA leading to disability. Our study is the first to use bright light therapy to improve sleep related functioning by reducing the residual daytime symptoms most strongly linked to disability in patients with sleep apnea

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The Equity in Maternal and Birthing outcomes and Reproductive HeAlth through Community Engagement (EMBRACE) Center of Excellence seeks to advance reproductive health and justice for Black populations in Allegheny County, Pennsylvania via multidisciplinary, community-centered research and training. Academic partners, practitioners and community leaders will work together to implement three multi-level research projects, supported and structured by components that prioritize community ownership, data transparency, and anti- oppression praxis. The intervention and implementation research generated from EMBRACE will address key factors related to maternal morbidity and mortality across the reproductive span among Black populations. Finally, EMBRACE will also set in motion necessary and sustainable improvements in academic-community partnerships, social services and health and health policy in our region.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative In this proposal, we seek to develop an innovative model of postpartum care for Black birthing people, a group with exceptionally high rates of severe maternal morbidity and maternal mortality because of structural and interpersonal racism, social determinants of health, and inadequate health care delivery. We will leverage community and training resources from the Equity in Birth Outcomes and Reproductive Health Through Community Engagement Center (EMBRACE) to develop and implement a new, integrative model of postpartum care that is culturally- and community-informed. We hypothesize that this new model of postpartum care will reduce severe maternal morbidity and maternal mortality and enhance health outcomes and well- being among Black birthing people.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Community Component of the EMBRACE (Equity in Maternal and Birthing Outcomes and Reproductive Health through Community Engagement) Center of Excellence will leverage existing networks to advance coordinated efforts of research and community agencies that are invested in maternal and child health through a strengths-based community-centered engagement strategy to promote bi-directional and process-driven learning, research, education, and training. The Community Component will work closely alongside EMBRACE Research Projects and Training Component to ensure equal and equitable practices through intentional integration of interdisciplinary community collaborators in all aspects of the research lifecycle; training and education opportunities; knowledge generation and skill-sharing; and dissemination and implementation of research findings. The Community Component will serve as trusted hub within EMBRACE for individuals and agencies to build community, capacity, and infrastructure for advancing Black maternal and child health and eliminating racial maternal health disparities in Allegheny County.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Peripheral nerve damage is a debilitating consequence of injury to the extremities of soldiers, long term consequences of which significantly impact Veterans, their caregivers, and the Veteran Healthcare System. In addition to loss of sensory and motor function, a particularly insidious and unsolved long-term consequence associated with nerve injury is a reduction in the structural integrity and strength of bone; this can increase risk of fracture as well as impact whole-body homeostasis. In this proposal, towards improved preservation and restoration of bone health following nerve injury, we propose to apply innovative magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) approaches to examine several structural and physiological properties of bone following nerve injury, nerve repair, and rehabilitative intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Epigenomics is the study of reversible genomic modification and organization, and how these processes control gene expression, variation and phenotypic programming. These modifications impact human health and disease, and research to understand their impact is necessarily a highly interdisciplinary endeavor. This workshop will enhance training of the biomedical research workforce by providing early stage researchers with a broad, integrated understanding of epigenomic technologies and software, and enabling them to address innovative, interdisciplinary questions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: NARRATIVE Smoking remains the leading cause of preventable morbidity and mortality in the United States, with tobacco use accounting for more deaths each year than the combined deaths attributable to alcohol, other drugs, homicide, suicide, motor vehicle accidents, and sexual behavior. Efficiently connecting underserved smokers with limited resources to efficacious tobacco cessation programs is crucial for disease prevention and the elimination of health disparities. This study seeks to address this need through partnering with a large social service network, the Regional Food Bank of Oklahoma, to evaluate the efficacy and economic impact of a theoretically-based, fully automated, interactive smartphone-based smoking cessation intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal examines the neural basis for how organisms make decisions about movements. Understanding neural activity in specific types of neurons under normal conditions, and how it is altered under pathological conditions, can contribute to improving treatments for movement disorders like Parkinson's disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: There is a rapidly growing interest in antibody-mediated drug delivery of immune stimulating payloads for the treatment of cancer. However, to-date these conjugates have been plagued by a high incidence of anti-drug antibodies (ADAs) that have prevented their clinical applications. The goal of this proposal is to demonstrate that our recently published Q295 conjugation technology reduces Fc-gamma uptake in antigen presenting cells (APCs) and masks the payloads from binding to ADAs by hiding them in a sterically occluded hydrophobic pocket in the Fc domain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Cross-organ sensitization is a common occurrence in patients and animals with bowel dysfunction. Glial cells are important players in sensory neuron sensitization and cross-activation. TrkB.T1 has a specific role in satellite glial cells of dorsal root ganglia to regulate sensory cross-activation and cross-organ sensitization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cancer is caused by DNA mutations, however, many lung cancer-causing chemicals do not directly damage DNA and are frequently tested as weak mutagens. This project will investigate a novel process through which a nonmutagenic metal nickel can produce cancer-promoting genetic damage. A completion of the proposed work will improve our understanding how a seemingly genetically harmless chemical can cause cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Liver transplantation is limited by the donor organ quality; however, preservation of donor allograft integrity will significantly improve the outcome following transplantation. Our studies will test the therapeutic benefit of a tissue repair protein, MG53, delivered via normothermic ex-vivo liver perfusion to preserve and rescue liver function prior to and after liver transplant surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative We will pursue studies in an incomplete model of chronic spinal cord injury (SCI), examining how a repeated treatment of transcutaneous stimulation contributes to decrease spasticity, hyperreflexia and improve motor function. We will determine if 6 weeks of repeated transcutaneous stimulation initiated acutely after injury before spasticity develops, or chronically once spasticity is established, leads to 1) a return in spinal inhibition, 2) an increase in motor output 3) improves locomotor recovery when delivered prior to a step-training program. Understanding the mechanisms underlying the beneficial effect of non-invasive interventions is critical to optimize clinical intervention and fast-track its use in the SCI community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Traditional protein-based subunit vaccine strategies are effective at generating antibody responses but incapable of boosting robust memory T cell responses. The goal of this translational project is to develop a prime/pull therapeutic genital herpes vaccine, using new antigen delivery systems, to boost the number and function of antiviral tissue-resident memory CD4+ and CD8+ T cells. The insights gained from this translational vaccine research will inform the design of a prime/pull therapeutic genital herpes vaccine to be tested in the clinic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Our studies indicate that USP7 inhibition activates p53-mediated tumor suppression by downregulating both Mdm2 and Mdmx and induces p53-independent tumor growth suppression by destabilizing N-Myc and PD-L1. The major hypothesis to be tested here is whether USP7 inhibitors are more effective and better therapeutic agents for the treatment of human cancers.
